You need to handle EEXIST.
Luckily that's only significant for the last component.
However if the the last component already exists,
it may not be a directory."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-06 02:17:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oops I missed you used os.path.exists().
So it's not too bad.

Now even if you used the preferable os.path.isdir()
it could still race with something else creating
the same dir, which is definitely possible.
How about:

    def mkdir_p(path):
        try:
            os.makedirs(path)
        except OSError as exc:
            if exc.errno == errno.EEXIST:
                if not os.path.isdir(path):
                    raise
            else:
                raise"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-08-06 02:34:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Padraig -- I nearly went that way, but then decided this was simpler. I missed the race condition though. I'm not sure its all that severe given the directories in question are instance  directories in very predictable locations, but I'm going to jump across to your version of the code anyways."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-08-06 02:34:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-06 02:55:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Remove unused InstanceInfo class.

We no longer use InstanceInfo.

Also removes some unused _map_to_instance_info functions in
various virt drivers.

commit_message:
Remove list_instances_detail from compute drivers.

Removes the list_instances_detail function from various compute drivers
which implement it. We no longer make use of this compute driver
call when syncing power states.

Change-Id: I4980bd8d4ec14c61e16d5be105659f0d5b6748ba

commit_message:
Migrate a logging change from common:

commit 58404a1a9461900367dbb7a8b3f2f98441e12959
Author: Mate Lakat <mate.lakat@citrix.com>
Date:   Tue Jul 31 17:53:57 2012 +0100

    Install a qualified except hook.

    Fixes bug 1031351.

    As an Exception is raised, it was not visible in the log, because
    it wasn't qualified. The fix sets up the exception hook to be
    qualified as the product_name.

Change-Id: I38c48d0dd2ac885fcb226310b6039be667af9e0d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-06 13:09:17.000000000', 'message': "all in one setup rc.local needs -p for midir command

bug fixes for swift 1033089
Swift 1.6.0 All in One setup uses rc.local to create a set of
directories like the following:
   /var/cache/swift /var/cache/swift2 /var/cache/swift3
   /var/cache/swift4
   /var/run/swift
without -p for mkdir command, when some of these directories
already exist, the rc.local fails so that the next set of
command won't execute. This causes swift fail to start because
of /var/run/swift does not exist. Adding -p to both mkdir
command solves this problem.

Change-Id: Ia26c9a857723747008293c0631c9acc1b58eca7e
"}, {'created': '2012-08-06 13:11:33.000000000', 'message': "all in one setup rc.local needs -p for mkdir command

bug fixes for swift 1033089
Swift 1.6.0 All in One setup uses rc.local to create a set of
directories like the following:
   /var/cache/swift /var/cache/swift2 /var/cache/swift3
   /var/cache/swift4
   /var/run/swift
without -p for mkdir command, when some of these directories
already exist, the rc.local fails so that the next set of
command won't execute. This causes swift fail to start because
of /var/run/swift does not exist. Adding -p to both mkdir
command solves this problem.

Change-Id: Ia26c9a857723747008293c0631c9acc1b58eca7e
"}]
commit_message:
all in one setup rc.local needs -p for mkdir command

bug fixes for swift 1033089
Swift 1.6.0 All in One setup uses rc.local to create a set of
directories like the following:
   /var/cache/swift /var/cache/swift2 /var/cache/swift3
   /var/cache/swift4
   /var/run/swift
without -p for mkdir command, when some of these directories
already exist, the rc.local fails so that the next set of
command won't execute. This causes swift fail to start because
of /var/run/swift does not exist. Adding -p to both mkdir
command solves this problem.

Change-Id: Ia26c9a857723747008293c0631c9acc1b58eca7e

commit_message:
Exempt openstack-common from pep8 check

The openstack-common project already does its own pep8 checks; we
don't need to duplicate the effort.  This also avoids issues with
pep8 version skew between projects.

Change-Id: I50d6e1b21c743d811e44b415017ca7e19687c9c2

commit_message:
Adds per-user-quotas support for more detailed quotas management

Implements blueprint per-user-quotas.

Based on the original quotas structure.

NOTE:
quota_instances, quota_cores, quota_ram, quota_volumes,
quota_gigabytes, quota_key_pairs and quota_security_groups
are supported per user.

Allow 'projectadmin' role to access the user quota setting
methods.

Add commands 'nova-manage quota project/user' for quotas
management.

Change-Id: I07a39499432571fedd819c53ae414240cefc3354

messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-03 10:10:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/6026/consoleFull : SUCCESS

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/5991/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-03 10:29:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Nice, much cleaner! However...

What about locks shared across NFS?
flock is documented not to support that,
but fcntl.F_GETLK does support it?
Should we use that instead?

This could be required as I've seen references to 
people using shared /var/lib/nova.

Also I had some notes on a shared lock dir
in the third comment on change Icff10ed75ba83f7256731614dc9e01e578b347a4"}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-03 11:19:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks p-draigbrady. To be honest, sharing locks over NFS seems like a bad idea to me and I couldn't find a real use-case for it. I'll have a look at fcntl locks and see if they provide the same guarantees / improvements. If not I'll poke openstack-dev to see how important NFS locks really are to people.

Another alternative could be to split local locks from possibly shared locks (local being iptables, shared being image ones) and allow choosing the strategy for shared ones, but that's just putting complexity on top of complexity."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-08-03 11:54:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

As a general rule flock() should always be avoided, in favour of fcntl() or lockf() which have more clearly defined semantics by the POSIX spec, as well as being functional over things like NFS."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-08-03 12:02:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-03 12:17:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Thanks Daniel, responded inline.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-08-03 12:46:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-03 14:19:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-03 14:25:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Moved to python's fcntl.lockf (uses fcntl internally), added a warning regarding closing the files (see previous comments), removed the lock cleanup script from tools since it's not needed anymore.

According to man pages, I should be ok with NFS now, but I'm not in a position to do serious testing with it."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-08-03 16:17:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Stan, do we have a bug or blueprint that we can use for tracking this enhancement/fix?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-08-03 16:21:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Besides the commit message including a bug/bp reference, the code looks excellent here. Nice cleanup, Stan.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-03 16:23:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This is a great cleanup.
thanks again.

On small caveat is that because the old lock file cleanup logic is gone, on upgrade from essex to folsom there could be stale lock files left. They shouldn't cause an issue though."}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-03 16:27:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'll register a blueprint and reference it in the message.

Re. the cleanup - I thought about keeping it, but that would mean all of the cleanup code would have to stay. And with that code the tests... so I decided to just delete it. May be a good paragraph for release notes.

Most likely I'll need to resubmit this change anyway since I broke Jenkins (all changes after mine got stuck... Monty got an email about it already)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-03 16:36:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/6031/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/1874/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/7186/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/3374/testReport : ABORTED
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/3396/testReport : ABORTED
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/6010/consoleFull : FAILURE
"}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-03 17:57:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Apparently there's a bug in eventlet-0.9.16 which caused the last deadlock on jenkins. I'll post a new version forcing in pip requires (0.9.17) after the weekend.
Created bp improve-external-locking"}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-04 00:29:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-04 00:54:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/6067/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/1910/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/7222/consoleFull : SUCCESS

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/3432/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/6088/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-04 04:09:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So on the dependencies.

I'd mention in the commit message that we're moving
from a platform agnostic lock file mechanism to
a UNIX specific one.

The new dependency on a specific eventlet version (0.9.17)
is valid, but not as part of this commit.
It's only part of this commit to work around a jenkins
deadlock issue triggered by it.
Also it's definitely worth documenting dependency changes
as much as possible, for the benefit of downstream consumers. To that end I've done the eventlet dep
in a separate I449f30afde7d162ed2c0df149174f1250ef378ca
which should be merged before any further versions
of this change are posted."}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-04 11:56:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-04 12:13:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Looking good now. Thanks!
I'll merge this after I449f30afde7d162ed2c0df149174f1250ef378ca lands."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-06 15:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Remove a number of limitations from the external locks.
- They can be nested now
- They do not need external cleanup in case of failures
- They do not rely on lockfile or greenlet internal implementation

commit_message:
Improve external lock implementation

Remove a number of limitations from the external locks.
- They can be nested now
- They do not need external cleanup in case of failures
- They do not rely on lockfile or greenlet internal implementation

New implementation is based on fcntl locks and any crashing process
will drop the lock. It does not have to rely on any cleanup code or
handling exceptions. Because no cleanup is needed, a number of tests
have been removed.
This implementation is not portable outside of POSIX/BSD/SVR4 systems.

Fcntl locks should work correctly with NFS mounts.

Locks are cleaned up after the tests finish running via run_tests.sh,
even though it's not strictly needed.

This change requires eventlet >= 0.9.17.

bp improve-external-locking

Change-Id: Idf5424c04645f25097733848a007b150145b0b27

[{'created': '2012-08-06 15:37:49.000000000', 'message': "Migrate a logging change from common:

commit 58404a1a9461900367dbb7a8b3f2f98441e12959
Author: Mate Lakat <mate.lakat@citrix.com>
Date:   Tue Jul 31 17:53:57 2012 +0100

    Install a qualified except hook.

    Fixes bug 1031351.

    As an Exception is raised, it was not visible in the log, because
    it wasn't qualified. The fix sets up the exception hook to be
    qualified as the product_name.

Change-Id: I2b26d625cc7b8c5351d7d92c14afd07a004d46ef
"}]
commit_message:
Migrate a logging change from common:

commit 58404a1a9461900367dbb7a8b3f2f98441e12959
Author: Mate Lakat <mate.lakat@citrix.com>
Date:   Tue Jul 31 17:53:57 2012 +0100

    Install a qualified except hook.

    Fixes bug 1031351.

    As an Exception is raised, it was not visible in the log, because
    it wasn't qualified. The fix sets up the exception hook to be
    qualified as the product_name.

Change-Id: I2b26d625cc7b8c5351d7d92c14afd07a004d46ef

Build successful

'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-07-31 23:11:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Couldnt this be a config option instead?"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-08-01 07:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

NB, the current behaviour of using a fixed, predictable name in /tmp is actually a security flaw, since it is vulnerable to tmpfile symlink attacks.

I don't think we should be using $HOME for this. IMHO system services/daemons should keep all their state / temporary files etc in appropriate application private directories in /var/cache, /var/run or /var/lib."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-08-01 12:26:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

chuck: this already is a config option. What this patchset does is change the default which is set when a config option isn't used

danpb: I agree that $HOME is a bad choice for this.

I suppose my vote would be that we default to /var/lib/$USER since most OpenStack services will follow the convention of running under a user account named after the service. Seems like a reasonable default.

Additionally, I think putting the option into the various paste file examples we have for auth_token in Nova, Glance, Swift, etc. is also probably a good idea. That doesn't affect what we use for a default here though."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-08-01 12:26:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-08-01 14:35:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think you guys are missing the point.  $HOME is for development, and for a safe option if the user does not put anything in the config file.

All of the other options require installer support.

The default for installed system should be /var/cache/<system>'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-08-01 14:35:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-01 15:00:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I think you guys are missing the point. $HOME is for development, and for a safe option if the user does not put anything in the config file.

IMHO, the defaults should be for a normal production deployment. For development environments it is perfectly reasonable to expect users to override it with an alternative location. Devstack could even automate this'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-08-02 19:25:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Devstack is a good tool, but it is  not the only way that people do development.  I don't really want to build an implied dependency between Keystone and Devstack in order to enable development.

/var/lib/<service> be a broken default. It would not work for anyone, since it would require explicit intervention on the part of the either the installer or the user to set the subdirectory under /var.  I would be more prone to remove the default altogether."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-08-02 21:56:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Use user home dir as default for cache

This is a better and safer default, as it and minimizes the
possibility that the cache directory will be prepopulated or
unwritable, while still providing a reasonable value for the
individual developer

Creates a better exception for failure to create the cache
dir

Logs the name of the cache dir actually used.

Bug 1031022

Change-Id: Ia3718107e436ceb034e3a89318ac05265d66d6f1

commit_message:
Add multiple-driver support to the notifier api.

Move all of the functionality previously provided by the list_notifier
into the basic notifier api.  Move and restructure tests accordingly.

Remove the list_notifier file and test file.

For bug 1025820

Change-Id: Idf7cb975dd78e9951188781622a4d10ca466b154

commit_message:
Only log deprecated config warnings once.

Updates Nova's deprecated warn function so that we only log
messages about deprecated config options once.

The motivation for this change is to cut down the log file noise
when deprecated config code gets called more than once.

Change-Id: If8919817330dc9461a0472fea982d43c78a86f66

commit_message:
Revert "Handle InstanceNotFound in libvirt list_instances."

This reverts commit be590cfa4b0025587a956642dc859902d577f3f7

The _conn.lookupByID() libvirt API cannot raise nova.exception.InstanceNotFound exceptions, only libvirt.libvirtError exceptions.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-03 17:24:19.000000000', 'message': 'Handle InstanceNotFound in libvirt list_instances.

Updates the libvirt driver so that InstanceNotFound is
handled within the list_instances function. This
can occur if an instance is deleted while the
list_instances function is processing.

Fixes LP Bug #1032741.
Change-Id: I97c9533f8b37957e71237c610ac360fbf9f57b9a
'}]
commit_message:
Handle InstanceNotFound in libvirt list_instances.

Updates the libvirt driver so that InstanceNotFound is
handled within the list_instances function. This
can occur if an instance is deleted while the
list_instances function is processing.

Fixes LP Bug #1032741.
Change-Id: I97c9533f8b37957e71237c610ac360fbf9f57b9a

Hi,
Please see my inline comment. Sorry if I am driving you crazy here. We all agree that the first 3 bytes should stay as defined. The open issue is how to indicate which additional bytes should be generated.
If you do choose to stick with the length check of the MAC then I think that a number of things should be done:
1. When the MAC is read from the configuration file the length should be checked.
2. The configuration file should be updated to indicate how the MAC address is used.
Maybe using the zero's to indicate which bytes should be generated is a decent way of addressing the problem.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-06 05:15:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-06 05:15:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Make 4th octet of mac_range configurable.

Fix bug 1022739.
To get OUI per cluster is not realistic. So This commit
make 4th octet of mac_range configurable. By this commit,
the cloud provider can allocate OUI (3 octets)  + 1 extra octet
range (4 octets) for each cluster.

Change-Id: Ibbd27e6e7f16d73dfd3045ed60f63a38b23ea1ed

Hi Rohit!

See inline for the things to fix up, and some commentary about rearranging the WhiteBoxManager into a tempest.whitebox.WhiteboxTest class.

Thanks!

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-07-06 15:56:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I have two issues about the way whitebox connections to compute/controller hosts is done here. First, though it is not used yet, it seems that the method that calls nova-manage is incorrectly assuming tempest is running on the same machine as the host. It needs to use ssh. 

On the ssh issue, some compute hosts may be configured to disallow ssh with password. Ideally there would also be a "path_to_private_key" parameter that could be used with ssh for such cases. But this code could be committed without that.

Also, subprocess.check_output does not exist in Python 2.6. Do we still care about 2.6?'}, {'account_id': 4120, 'date': '2012-07-06 18:01:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

Holding up my remaining Patch comments and subsequent patch until I work on David's concerns. 

David, on the nova-manage issue, I think passing an optional flag_file(essex) or config_file(master) parameter to nova-manage should solve it. The nova.conf should contain the 'sql_connection' parameter using which it can make calls to a db on a remote machine. Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-07-06 18:18:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

What I was trying to say was that you need to ssh into the controller node to run nova-manage. So the config has to tell you which node that is.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-07-10 17:59:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 18:51:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Refactoring of base test case classes

* Splits out the "manager" class into its own file (at least
  for now to keep the code change size down initially)
* Adds base manager classes for Fuzz and Default clients
* Adds base test case class and a derived base SmokeTest class
* Adds smoke test for basic server operations in compute
* Adds non-smoke test for advanced server operations in compute

Change-Id: Ib87da825f05550d625a08aa1fe82bfaa921e80f9

Adds Whitebox manager and Servers Whitebox tests

This change (Draft) builds upon the proposed refactoring to the Tempest Manager
and base test classes as per https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7069

* Adds a whitebox manager subclass to base Manager providing database, ssh
and nova-manage access and related configs
* Adds inital set of whitebox tests for Compute and Images API

Change-Id: Ib87c3dadcb233f9d1e8e38365960ad71d166913a

whoops, looks like i commented on a slightly older version.  please ignore comments if they are no longer relevant.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-06 01:02:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

I'm posting a new patch set with some of Yong's comments addressed. I'm holding off on his comments about naming until the 2nd phase of the provider-networks BP implementation, which will be renaming some of these tables and functions. I've had to update the linuxbridge plugin due to removing the net_id from the VlanIdInUse exception.

I spoke with Dan regarding the VLAN ID usage in tunnel mode. Its clear that the vlan_id column in the vlan_bindings table is used for a "logical switch id" (lsw_id) in tunnel mode, and that this is different than the (sort of real) VLAN ID allocated locally by the agent. In both tunnel mode and VLAN mode, the vlan_bindings entries are one-to-one mappings between net_ids and integers. None of the changes in this patch affect that usage. I am considering Dan's suggestion to store the net_id->lsw_id mapping in a separate table in phase 2 of the provider-networks BP.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-06 01:02:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (7 inline comments)

Hi Yong,

I'm not sure what you are suggesting I talk to Dan about. Is this related to my changing the primary key in the vlan_bindings table? If so, I don't think my change has modified the way that vlan_binding records are created or managed at all. The agent simply queries the entire table, and then processes them in memory. Both the vlan_id and the network_id in the record have always had to be unique within the table. No agent-specific vlan IDs are being allocated in the current code. Can you and/or Dan clarify please? I do understand that with tunnelling, these aren't really VLANs on the wire, and that they could be separately managed by each agent, but tunnel mode currently just lets the server assign them globally just like it does in vlan mode."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-08-06 01:02:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

Here are the newer comments on the older patch set.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-06 01:02:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Replace openvswitch plugin's VlanMap with vlan_ids DB table.

Fixes bug 1023167.

The openswitch plugin's in-memory VlanMap is replaced with a vlan_ids
DB table similar to that used by the linuxbridge plugin. This will
prevent conflicting VLAN assignments if multiple server replicas are
run, and also sets the stage for phase 2 of the provider-networks BP
implementation that will add support for multiple physical
networks.

Unlike with the current linuxbridge plugin, the contents of the
openvswitch plugin's vlan_ids table are properly updated at startup in
case the vlan_min or vlan_max configuration variables have changed.

A new test_ovs_db test case has been added.

The primary key of the vlan_bindings table is changed from the vlan_id
to the network_id, which is now a foreign key, and network deletion is
now properly handled.

The net_id has been removed from the VlanIdInUse exception, requiring
a minor update to the linuxbridge plugin. The new NoNetworksAvailable
exception, with ResourceExhausted as its base class, is returned when
no more VLANs are available.

Change-Id: I65a2347dea5366cc0d15d98a88f40e42e1a45f4c

commit_message:
Handle NetworkNotFound in _shutdown_instance.

If no network is found, continue to perform the rest of the instance
shutdown, instead of propogating the exception. Resolves bug 1008875.

Change-Id: Ia78480edaed52932830da7b4e49c15fd2e1fa315

Change-Id: Ib345970743d542afb65b7fb6980d6d369d757ad2

commit_message:
Admin users should be restricted from seeing all
snapshots by default.

  * Now to view all snapshots across all tenants you need
    to include the all_tenants=1 GET param in your api request.
  * Fixes remaining issues blocking bug #967882

Change-Id: Ib345970743d542afb65b7fb6980d6d369d757ad2

commit_message:
Remove **kwargs from prep_resize in compute manager.

The only place where additional arguments were being passed in was via
the unit tests, and they aren't used.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I13f4a209ac9acc732966cb6e01bdbbcc3e3bd3c8

[{'created': '2012-08-02 23:33:45.000000000', 'message': 'Updates to the prep_resize scheduler rpc call.

I started looking at this because of the prep_resize rpc call in the compute
manager.  An API server calls prep_resize on the scheduler which then calls it
on a compute node.  I will need to make the same changes on the compute side,
but this is the first step.

The prep_resize call was taking two object IDs, an instance UUID and an
instance_type ID.  Both of these have been converted.  It now takes an instance
dict and an instance_type dict, instead.  It can also handle receiving the old
IDs for backwards compatibility.  prep_resize also took a topic argument that
was unused, so it has just been removed.

There are a number of changes in the scheduler code tied up in this to make it
more explicit about exactly what arguments are expected instead of just using
*args, **kwargs.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I4af18e5575e2bb60a410fc8edabf3d607c72aabc

commit_message:
Updates to the prep_resize scheduler rpc call.

I started looking at this because of the prep_resize rpc call in the compute
manager.  An API server calls prep_resize on the scheduler which then calls it
on a compute node.  I will need to make the same changes on the compute side,
but this is the first step.

The prep_resize call was taking two object IDs, an instance UUID and an
instance_type ID.  Both of these have been converted.  It now takes an instance
dict and an instance_type dict, instead.  It can also handle receiving the old
IDs for backwards compatibility.  prep_resize also took a topic argument that
was unused, so it has just been removed.

There are a number of changes in the scheduler code tied up in this to make it
more explicit about exactly what arguments are expected instead of just using
*args, **kwargs.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I4af18e5575e2bb60a410fc8edabf3d607c72aabc

commit_message:
Drop AES functions and pycrypto dependency

At some point IV parameter has been removed making these functions
dangerous to use unless keys are unique on every message. Since the
functions were added the original consumer has disappeared too. With
no more users it's better to get rid of the incomplete encryption system
entirely.

These were the only functions using pycrypto module directly, so it was
also removed from the dependency list.

Change-Id: I57b0a0a42dac455d5baae3d726aea1507121aa4d

commit_message:
Update reset_db to call setup if _DB is None.

This resolves issues when running individual tests that require
a database. With this fix I can once again run individual test
modules that make use of the database. For example:

  ./run_tests.sh test_libvirt

Previously this would fail with database errors.

Fixes LP Bug #1032738.

Change-Id: Icce7ac9414f0e19eece44819a217634947de7f73

subject: Simplify file hashing
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-04 17:27:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/6115/consoleFull : SUCCESS

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/3476/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/6136/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-04 21:41:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

map is lazy in python 3 and you could make map lazy in python 2 in the function, like:

if sys.version_info < (3,):
    map=itertools.imap

So for a 10G file, in cpython in x86_64, the mem taken for the redundant list is 2.4MiB.
That's significant enough and the code above obtuse enough,
that I agree with the change.

The downside is that the 305,175 loops will be done in bytecode now,
but that shouldn't be the bottleneck anyway."}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-04 22:07:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I could do `any(checksum.update(chunk) for chunk in ...)` if you prefer? Although I don't think it will make much difference regarding bytecode/runtime exec time."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-04 22:25:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Yes I would prefer since it saves a few cycles and a line of code (assuming you s/chunk/c/). It won't save any time, but think of the electrons! :)"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-04 22:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Actually while you're at it, can you s/''/b''/ to make it python 3 compatible. That's supported by python 2.6 too.
so we have:

    def hash_file(file_obj):
        """Generate a hash for the contents of a file."""
        checksum = hashlib.sha1()
        any(checksum.update(c) for c in iter(lambda: file_obj.read(32768), b'')))
        return checksum.hexdigest()

cheers'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-04 22:53:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok - if we're bikeshedding, let's do it properly:

x=[None]*100+[b'']
def disregard(e): pass
i=iter(x)
%timeit any(disregard(c) for c in iter(lambda: i.next(), b''))
# 100000 loops, best of 3: 1.22 us per loop
%timeit for e in iter(lambda: i.next(), ''): disregard(e)
# 1000000 loops, best of 3: 772 ns per loop

common loop wins. I'll add the binary prefix and rename the topic to useless-benchmarking ;)"}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-05 00:21:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-05 00:38:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/6136/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/1975/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/7287/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/3475/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/3497/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/6159/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-08-05 00:44:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

b'' added, for left. Also the last review was supposed to be fun/silly. If it wasn't, I blame the internets transport ;)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-05 01:16:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-05 01:16:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

No worries, code golf is always fun.
Thanks for satisfying my OCD tonight :)

Note in testing here I found the timings closer.
For a normal case of 100K chunks/file,
I found the overhead of the various methods to be:

    53.5ms: itertools.imap
    58.3ms: for c in iter(...) (current patch)
    63.3ms: any(list comprehension)
    63.5ms: standard python, while True: ...

Hence it's good to go..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-05 01:33:30.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-05 01:33:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

'}]

commit_message:
Simplify file hashing

Since map() is not lazy, hash_file() created huge lists filled with
`None` when hashing large files. Rewriting it to a simple loop prevents
that.

Change-Id: I65681f905bacc2afda52853bbe9e364b89f515a8

commit_message:
Fix notification logic

Notifications were always treated as if they're about state changes
due to a typo. Additionally exception handler did not work correctly.
Regression tests included.

Change-Id: I0b92a1baa17768d9cf4e709b3331480548dd041e

commit_message:
Remove unused variables

fetch() no longer returns metadata so fetch_to_raw does not need to pass it.
Callers don't expect the return value either.

Output of execute() is not used for anything

Change-Id: I84be22e042696a51eb919f6c6f0ccf58aaf3ace3

commit_message:
Update list_instances to catch libvirtError.

Commit be590cfa4b0025587a956642dc859902d577f3f7 caught (and tested
for) the wrong exception. lookupByID throws a libvirtError.

Fixes LP Bug #1032741.

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-07-27 21:17:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

-1 until this gets clarified, but I think the create-server-ext is also associated with passing in networks + ip addresses as part of the POST when creating a server (hence, the name)."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-07-27 21:28:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

To be clear, I'm talking about the ability to specify a "networks" field when creating a server, see: 

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L640

The tests in test_createserverext.py seem to tests this functionality heavily, which is weak evidence that the "os-createserverext" was originally intended to cover the "networks" functionality as well.  Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-27 22:18:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dan: it appears that may be the documented purpose of the extension but the extension doesn't actually do anything related to it. All of those creates work posting against /servers as well."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-07-27 23:42:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

oh, definitely.  I was just wondering about the case where someone might want to check if the os-createserverext was in the list of available extensions before passing "networks" when creating a server.   

Its not a big deal, I just wanted to be clear that if we were actually planning on deprecating the portion of the os-createservext that involved passing networks in on boot, I would have a concern.

Removing my -1 now that I've said my piece :)'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-29 20:28:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dan: I'm going to discuss the lack of post extensions in the first nova meeting next week."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-31 15:30:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

Looks good, some comments inline though

The current extension seems to be pretty silly, but it's not clear to me whether it originally made any sense and, if it did, when it lost its original purpose

For reference, here's the merge prop which originally added the extension - https://code.launchpad.net/~tpatil/nova/add-options-network-create-os-apis/+merge/68292

The security groups bit wasn't added until https://code.launchpad.net/~tpatil/nova/bug838251/+merge/73725"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-31 16:59:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Going to rework this a bit with some new thoughts on extension mechanism.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-04 20:26:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

reworked into new patchset:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/10815/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-27 20:30:57.000000000', 'message': 'Adds extension for displaying security groups

Implements blueprint deprecate-createserverext

The createserverext extension creates a new endpoint for the
sole purpose of displaying security groups. Security groups should
be displayed via an output extension instead, and be properly
namesapeced.

This commit adds an extension do do the above and marks the
createserverext extension deprecated so it can be removed. It
also sets policy to allow all users to access the extension by
default.

Tests are included to ensure that the groups are returned in both
json and xml.

Change-Id: I26b90548d72efb5408cca93aaf6f9b7d08c56e56
'}]
commit_message:
Adds extension for displaying security groups

Implements blueprint deprecate-createserverext

The createserverext extension creates a new endpoint for the
sole purpose of displaying security groups. Security groups should
be displayed via an output extension instead, and be properly
namesapeced.

This commit adds an extension do do the above and marks the
createserverext extension deprecated so it can be removed. It
also sets policy to allow all users to access the extension by
default.

Tests are included to ensure that the groups are returned in both
json and xml.

Change-Id: I26b90548d72efb5408cca93aaf6f9b7d08c56e56

commit_message:
update DHCP agent to work with linuxbridge plug-in

Fixes bug: 1027194

Update the interface driver to use veths instead of tap devices.  This
change is compatible with the netns work.

Change-Id: Ic236f5fdeb79eb36791434999df2b731856de092

[{'created': '2012-08-04 04:05:23.000000000', 'message': 'Require eventlet >= 0.9.17

0.9.17 was released 2012-08-03 and
includes two particular fixes related to OpenStack

1. https://bitbucket.org/which_linden/eventlet/issue/123/
Fix an exception thrown by epoll in certain cases.
This can cause jenkins to deadlock, triggered for example by:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/10767/

2. https://bitbucket.org/which_linden/eventlet/issue/115/
   https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/903199
Fix a significant memory leak of _DummyThread objects.

Change-Id: I449f30afde7d162ed2c0df149174f1250ef378ca
'}]
commit_message:
Require eventlet >= 0.9.17

0.9.17 was released 2012-08-03 and
includes two particular fixes related to OpenStack

1. https://bitbucket.org/which_linden/eventlet/issue/123/
Fix an exception thrown by epoll in certain cases.
This can cause jenkins to deadlock, triggered for example by:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/10767/

2. https://bitbucket.org/which_linden/eventlet/issue/115/
   https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/903199
Fix a significant memory leak of _DummyThread objects.

Change-Id: I449f30afde7d162ed2c0df149174f1250ef378ca

    and doesn't really belong in openstack-common's generic logging
    configuration.

by

should

    Fixes LP Bug #1029577.

Change-Id: Ic6a6862e5bc357846bf3202186c7e24622d3bb87
"}]
commit_message:
Sync w/ latest openstack common log.py.

Includes the following updates for openstack-common's log.py:

    Remove code to clear basicConfig root log handlers

    Removes some old Nova specific code to clear out the log handlers
    from Nova's logging basicConfig. This code is arguably Nova specific
    and doesn't really belong in openstack-common's generic logging
    configuration.

    Additionally, This code was actually removing the root logger used
by
    some command line tools and binaries and hiding log messages that
should
    have otherwise gone to the console.

    Fixes LP Bug #1029577.

Change-Id: Ic6a6862e5bc357846bf3202186c7e24622d3bb87

I like that this fix is small, contained, and fixes the bug, but I really dislike the general strategy used by this section of code. Storing state information internally in a class and then serializing the whole class is just a recipe for a disaster in the future if we need to change anything.

I would much prefer it if the underlying disk.py classes could do their job without needing to maintain internal state, but that may be a largish refactor. In the absence of that, I would be ok writing out the necessary state to disk in a common format like json or text via a serialize and deserialize method. Then we at least have a chance of maintaining compatibility if we upgrade the class later."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-01 19:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Yes agreed. It's better to store an abstract format.

I'll keep in mind trying to have all state external,
but couldn't see an way to do that so far."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-02 14:49:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

I was able to come up with a version that recalculates the state, rather than storing stuff externally.

I tested it successfully on fedora with all of loop,nbd,libguestfs on partitioned and non partitioned images.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-08-02 15:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-02 15:26:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-01 14:49:59.000000000', 'message': 'fix unmounting of LXC containers

There were two issues here.

1. There was a global object stored for all instances,
thus the last mounted instance was always unmounted.

2. Even if there was only a single LXC instance in use,
the global object would be lost on restart of Nova.

Therefore we pickle the "umount object" alongside
the LXC mount directory in the instances dir.
(which is around 600 bytes).

A generic umount(dir) doesn't work as we need to
handle qemu-nbd and libguestfs specially, so we
store this extra info to tear down the mount fully.

Fixes bug: 971621
Change-Id: I5442442f00d93f5e8b82f492d62918419db5cd3b
'}, {'created': '2012-08-02 15:07:54.000000000', 'message': 'fix unmounting of LXC containers

There were two issues here.

1. There was a global object stored for all instances,
thus the last mounted instance was always unmounted.

2. Even if there was only a single LXC instance in use,
the global object would be lost on restart of Nova.

Therefore we reset the internal state for the mount object,
by passing in the mount point to destroy_container(),
and querying the device in use for that mount point.

Fixes bug: 971621
Change-Id: I5442442f00d93f5e8b82f492d62918419db5cd3b
'}, {'created': '2012-08-02 20:54:39.000000000', 'message': 'fix unmounting of LXC containers

There were two issues here.

1. There was a global object stored for all instances,
thus the last mounted instance was always unmounted.

2. Even if there was only a single LXC instance in use,
the global object would be lost on restart of Nova.

Therefore we reset the internal state for the mount object,
by passing in the mount point to destroy_container(),
and querying the device in use for that mount point.

Fixes bug: 971621
Change-Id: I5442442f00d93f5e8b82f492d62918419db5cd3b
'}]
commit_message:
fix unmounting of LXC containers

There were two issues here.

1. There was a global object stored for all instances,
thus the last mounted instance was always unmounted.

2. Even if there was only a single LXC instance in use,
the global object would be lost on restart of Nova.

Therefore we reset the internal state for the mount object,
by passing in the mount point to destroy_container(),
and querying the device in use for that mount point.

Fixes bug: 971621
Change-Id: I5442442f00d93f5e8b82f492d62918419db5cd3b

commit_message:
Force rpm to retry indefinately during crankcase build

If RPM is not forced, sometimes packages will fail to download within the
default 10 retries.  This results in crankcase failing to build OpenShift.

Change-Id: I5174928fc2ac205dcd7818ecf1da6b8e32f48e08
Signed-off-by: Steven Dake <sdake@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-27 12:56:00.000000000', 'message': 'Partially revert "Remove unused scheduler functions"

This partially reverts commit 2aaa3d2860eed7574c5df64a8ceeb8a6adf23460.

The problem pointed out by this bug is that these changes introduce a
non-backwards compatibile change to the schedulre rpc API.  There are a
couple of acceptable ways to deal with this:

1) Leave most of the code and only remove the client side.  This means
   that a message sent from an earlier version will still work.  This is
   the ideal situation for almost *all* changes to rpc APIs.  We have to
   make a habit of this to eventually be able to support rolling
   upgrades.

2) Leave the manager methods, but simply have them raise an exception.
   This is a bit better than removing the method because the error
   can be made more explicit and obvious.  Otherwise, the operator will
   get "no such method" rpc exceptions, which will seem a bit more
   bizzare.

   An example of when this option makes sense is commit
   cac332c39645286a11c009094a86f62d02752183.  This patch refactored the
   live migration code is such a significant way that making it
   backwards compatibile seemed rather difficult to do.  The old rpc
   methods stuck around but just raise an exception.  The potential
   failure is just that live migration would fail, but the exception
   makes it obvious that an upgrade must be completed for live migration
   to work.

The current patch implements #1.

Fix bug 1029262.

Change-Id: I74c7d2a3e88b3a4f114e7da62c56f0481ee64a64
'}, {'created': '2012-07-31 18:15:18.000000000', 'message': 'Partially revert "Remove unused scheduler functions"

1) Leave most of the code and only remove the client side.  This means

   the ideal situation for almost *all* changes to rpc APIs.  We have to
   make a habit of this to eventually be able to support rolling
   upgrades.

2) Leave the manager methods, but simply have them raise an exception.
   This is a bit better than removing the method because the error
   can be made more explicit and obvious.  Otherwise, the operator will
   get "no such method" rpc exceptions, which will seem a bit more
   bizzare.

   An example of when this option makes sense is commit
   cac332c39645286a11c009094a86f62d02752183.  This patch refactored the
   live migration code is such a significant way that making it
   backwards compatibile seemed rather difficult to do.  The old rpc
   methods stuck around but just raise an exception.  The potential
   failure is just that live migration would fail, but the exception
   makes it obvious that an upgrade must be completed for live migration
   to work.

The current patch implements #2 in the case of get_service_capabilities,
since it hasn't been used since pre-essex.  A couple of other functions
were completely removed host_manager, as they were just used internally
and never over rpc (host_service_caps_stale and
delete_expired_host_services).

The patch uses approach #1 for get_host_list().  It just changes
the way it is implemented to get the data out of the database.  This is
the same way the hosts extension to the compute API works.

Fix bug 1029262.

Change-Id: I74c7d2a3e88b3a4f114e7da62c56f0481ee64a64
'}, {'created': '2012-07-31 18:20:10.000000000', 'message': 'Partially revert "Remove unused scheduler functions"

2) Leave the manager methods, but simply have them raise an exception.

   to work.

The current patch implements #2 in the case of get_service_capabilities,
since it hasn't been used since pre-essex.  Approach #2 is taken for
get_host_list() as well.  It was used until fairly recently, but was
broken, including being broken in Essex.  The fix that went into Essex
for this makes it no longer use RPC.

Fix bug 1029262.

Change-Id: I74c7d2a3e88b3a4f114e7da62c56f0481ee64a64

commit_message:
Partially revert "Remove unused scheduler functions"

This partially reverts commit 2aaa3d2860eed7574c5df64a8ceeb8a6adf23460.

The problem pointed out by this bug is that these changes introduce a
non-backwards compatibile change to the schedulre rpc API.  There are a
couple of acceptable ways to deal with this:

1) Leave most of the code and only remove the client side.  This means
   that a message sent from an earlier version will still work.  This is
   the ideal situation for almost *all* changes to rpc APIs.  We have to
   make a habit of this to eventually be able to support rolling
   upgrades.

2) Leave the manager methods, but simply have them raise an exception.
   This is a bit better than removing the method because the error
   can be made more explicit and obvious.  Otherwise, the operator will
   get "no such method" rpc exceptions, which will seem a bit more
   bizzare.

   An example of when this option makes sense is commit
   cac332c39645286a11c009094a86f62d02752183.  This patch refactored the
   live migration code is such a significant way that making it
   backwards compatibile seemed rather difficult to do.  The old rpc
   methods stuck around but just raise an exception.  The potential
   failure is just that live migration would fail, but the exception
   makes it obvious that an upgrade must be completed for live migration
   to work.

The current patch implements #2 in the case of get_service_capabilities,
since it hasn't been used since pre-essex.  Approach #2 is taken for
get_host_list() as well.  It was used until fairly recently, but was
broken, including being broken in Essex.  The fix that went into Essex
for this makes it no longer use RPC.

Fix bug 1029262.

Change-Id: I74c7d2a3e88b3a4f114e7da62c56f0481ee64a64

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-26 13:31:57.000000000', 'message': 'Fix broken pep8 exclude processing.

First of all, our pep8 exclude was excluding openstack, to trap
for not doing pep8 checks on openstack/common, which comes from elsewhere.
But, pep8 senseless strips filenames down to basename when doing
exclude checks on them, which makes no sense.
To fix this, grab the two functions from pep8, fix them, and monkeypatch them
from within hacking.py.
Next, we need to submit these as fixes upstream.

Also, changed the exclude to catch just openstack/common.

Change-Id: If0b18ae828e74203f84a8b6f8b4ba0100b3bbc59

commit_message:
Fix broken pep8 exclude processing.

First of all, our pep8 exclude was excluding openstack, to trap
for not doing pep8 checks on openstack/common, which comes from elsewhere.
But, pep8 strips filenames down to basename when doing exclude checks on
them, which makes no sense. To fix this, grab the two functions from pep8,
fix them, and monkeypatch them from within hacking.py.

Patch has been submitted upstream as:

  https://github.com/jcrocholl/pep8/pull/111

Also, changed the exclude to catch just openstack/common.

Change-Id: If0b18ae828e74203f84a8b6f8b4ba0100b3bbc59

commit_message:
Adds proper response checking to HTTP Store.

The HTTP Store now handles the following cases:

  * Redirects are resolved (infinite redirect chains are prevented).
  * 4xx and 5xx status codes result in a proper exception instead
    of trying to continue with the image.

Fixes bug 1009248.

Change-Id: Ibc44413d630bf35e0c396adc430c39f4295030fd

[{'created': '2012-08-03 22:05:27.000000000', 'message': 'Rename _self to self according to Python convention

If self is never used, it should probably be defined as a classmethod
or a staticmethod, instead of _self. Use "self" for now to stick
to python convention, and leave proper refactor to other patches.

Change-Id: I71de42ffd3e83c57772b6490c52f24bcd9d1f1ea
'}]
commit_message:
Rename _self to self according to Python convention

If self is never used, it should probably be defined as a classmethod
or a staticmethod, instead of _self. Use "self" for now to stick
to python convention, and leave proper refactor to other patches.

Change-Id: I71de42ffd3e83c57772b6490c52f24bcd9d1f1ea

commit_message:
Ensure that we have access to sbin binaries through sudo

We need to add the sbin paths to the secure path in sudoers for the user
running the script, to make sure that running sbin binaries from sudo
will work.

Change-Id: I7942407df768bfa8dd035f15fa8b43ba05319779

commit_message:
Addition of base Smoke and Whitebox tests

* Splits out the "manager" class into its own file (at least
  for now to keep the code change size down initially)
* Adds base manager classes for Fuzz and Default clients
* Adds base test case class and a derived base SmokeTest class
* Adds smoke test for basic server operations in compute
* Adds non-smoke test for advanced server operations in compute
* Adds Whitebox base test case class
* New basic db-checking whitebox tests for servers and images

This change builds upon the proposed refactoring to the Tempest Manager
and base test classes as per https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7069

Change-Id: I12125fffb725cad3a4fef3134c83e55437529252

commit_message:
Admin users should be restricted from seeing all
volumes by default.

  * Now to view all volumes across all tenants you need
    to include the all_tenants=1 GET param in your api request.
  * Fixes remaining issues blocking bug #967882

Change-Id: Ie9d74e9c09fa0c192ab6257b5fb02d65b593cbfb

Store context in local thread store for logging.

This also fixes the logging of request ids for every request.

Fixes bug 1031596

Change-Id: Ifd0217c99402316214efaf1fe8533c60c2277257

COMPUTE_BIN_DIR

These options are used in an upcoming Tempest patchset

Change-Id: I50409d03255b92f154112b57e96ad71f8542ac96

commit_message:
Adds compute whitebox configuration options

Adds the following options to the tempest configuration
file:

COMPUTE_CONFIG_PATH
COMPUTE_SOURCE_DIR
COMPUTE_WHITEBOX_ENABLED
COMPUTE_PATH_TO_PRIVATE_KEY
COMPUTE_DB_URI
COMPUTE_BIN_DIR

These options are used in an upcoming Tempest patchset

Change-Id: I50409d03255b92f154112b57e96ad71f8542ac96

commit_message:
Only generate versioninfo in our own repo.

We were doing some blind re-generation in some contexts, so that when
a pbr managed library was installed in the source dir of a different
project that was also in git, we'd re-write an incorrect version.

Change-Id: I540b3f12d9e3682959089523e13cd290682fdaa8

[{'created': '2012-08-03 17:42:50.000000000', 'message': "Don't trust the delete API.

Don't believe the API if it says it deleted a server.  Instead,

remove it from the DB.

Change-Id: I76a01f0c8a1e777d203e98d2c3623802634a4bc3
"}]
commit_message:
Don't trust the delete API.

Don't believe the API if it says it deleted a server.  Instead,
wait until the server doesn't show up in the future, and only then,
remove it from the DB.

Change-Id: I76a01f0c8a1e777d203e98d2c3623802634a4bc3

commit_message:
Use the workspace cache.

The update vm job was caching git repos, but the gate job wasn't
using them.

Change-Id: I20d6bed6724ef131109fe3ccfe2b11e34edc8a96

commit_message:
rpc: remove cast_to_server() functions

Fixes bug #1031709
Part of blueprint rpc-api-review

These functions were added to Nova by commit c729ba8 6 months ago and
have never been used by Nova or any of the other projects using the
common RPC API.

Remove the APIs for now until they are actually needed since they will
be more difficult to remove in future after we do a library release of
openstack-common which includes the RPC API.

Change-Id: I89afc2bcd60e6d8a5056f7ac9ebbf8790cf27ccc

commit_message:
Fix logic on root_helper deprecation warning.

Updates the logic which determines when we log a deprecation warning
for the old root_helper config. We only want to log this warning
if the new rootwrap_config is None *AND* the old root_helper option
is not set to the default value (sudo).

Fixes LP Bug #1032657.

Change-Id: Ief0dc9cc75effd4bd7e775a002aad51a1a64b87b

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

Just scanned code, overall it looks good.  I think most of the questions are around the scope of notifications, and how it will interact with plugin agents.  My suggestion is for Yong, Gary, and a couple others to coordinate on a spec for notifications, focusing on what use cases we are or are not trying to solve with this first version, and how this notifications work interacts with other efforts within Quantum to eliminate polling by agents (I'm hoping it can be the basis for that, rather than us creating ad-hoc RPC calls)."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

pending discussion today, i'm removing my -1.  Sounds like best approach (for F-3 at least) may be to treat notifications as completely separate from gary's RPC branch."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

A few weeks ago at the weekly meeting it was decided that we should remain with the plugin.ini files. I too was in favor of moving to one merged file, but the consensus was to remain with the same files.
I guess that we can bring this up at tomorrow's meeting"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

Hi,
The code looks good. I have a number of issues.
1. In the event of an error int he operation then I think that he notification may also need to be invoked
2. From my experience with the RPC integration into the agents at times the opertaions may be blocking => the operation may have to wait a timeout. Is this relevant here?
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (8 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

IMO, RPC and notification is different concept.
Notification is for some distributed logging or metering purpose, so it will just send information in one direction.

But It is different for RPC. It may require callback or return from caller.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

Hi Gary,

We have to think about the location of the configuration items.

It seems our configuration files are still sprawling. Why do we still need the quantum.conf, and specific plugin file? Can't we merge them into quantum.conf.
To put these notification's configuration into plugin conf files seems unreasonable.

Thanks

Yong Sheng Gong"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-08-03 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

Gary,

commit_message:
Notification for network/subnet/port create/delete/update.
blueprint quantum-notifications

Add host configuration into conf, which is determined by socket.gethostname()
function by default. Host name is part of publiser id, which is in the format
of 'network'.$host.

We add create/update/delete start and end notification for each kind of resource.
By default, the notification do nothing since the notifier driver is no_op_notifier.
We can define it in quantum.conf.

Change-Id: Ibc5eacac7a324584e6ccff120f573444932a88ef

That section could be updated. Actually the described process is complicated while it could be simpler. I used to work with CSScorp step-by-step (for instance http://cssoss.wordpress.com/2011/11/28/bundling-debian-image-for-openstack/)
The steps roughly are always the same : 
#1- get iso/ boot on it/ install it the way you want
#2- rc.local instruction/ clean udev rules
#3- voila.

It becomes cumbersome when you want to be able to specify your own kernel instead of embedding it into the image. Maybe we could split the guide in two sections ?
#Section 1 : whole/ autonomous image
#Section 2 : data image only, require a kernel (that would be specified during the glance upload ?'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-08-01 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Document how to create qcow and raw images.

This is the beginning of a refactoring of the section on creating
images. This change describes how to create QCOW2 and raw images,
using CentOS as an example.

I would like to eventually remove the existing docs on creating a
raw image, since it's out of date, but I wanted to get this
replacement doc get in for review first.

Change-Id: Ic4564833e453ee34deafedb3f5621d74624aef20

commit_message:
Port existing rpc calls to use the new RPC client API.

Patch 2/2, this implements github heat issue 181.

test_api_v1 was modified to handle the extra rpc arguments.

metadata_register_address hasn't been included in EngineAPI, and it
possibly doesn't deserve to. This means that bin/heat-metadata has the
only remaining raw rpc call.

[{'created': '2012-08-03 02:00:58.000000000', 'message': "Implements a client side engine RPC API.

Patch 1/2, this implements github heat issue 181.

The topic string for the rpc call is built from the cfg.CONF parameters 'host'
and 'engine_topic' defined in heat.common.config.engine_opts.

delete_stack seems to be the only method which returns nothing, so it can be
invoked as cast or call, with cast being the default.

The tests exercise each api method with the same approach found in
nova/nova/tests/compute/test_rpcapi.py

Change-Id: Ia20850821083d1236ad628172db00d01f073313c
"}, {'created': '2012-08-03 02:00:58.000000000', 'message': "Implements a client side RPC API which exposes engine and metadata methods.

This implements github heat issue 181.

The topic string for the rpc call is built from the cfg.CONF parameters 'host'
and 'engine_topic' defined in heat.common.config.engine_opts.

delete_stack seems to be the only method which returns nothing, so it can be
invoked as cast or call, with cast being the default.

The tests exercise each api method with the same approach found in
nova/nova/tests/compute/test_rpcapi.py

A future change could convert the raw rpc calls found in these files to use
this client API:
bin/heat-metadata
heat/api/v1/stacks.py
heat/metadata/api/v1/metadata.py

Also heat-boto should probably be ported to this from the Amazon API.

Change-Id: Ia20850821083d1236ad628172db00d01f073313c
"}]
commit_message:
Implements a client side engine RPC API.

Patch 1/2, this implements github heat issue 181.

The topic string for the rpc call is built from the cfg.CONF parameters 'host'
and 'engine_topic' defined in heat.common.config.engine_opts.

delete_stack seems to be the only method which returns nothing, so it can be
invoked as cast or call, with cast being the default.

The tests exercise each api method with the same approach found in
nova/nova/tests/compute/test_rpcapi.py

Change-Id: Ia20850821083d1236ad628172db00d01f073313c

commit_message:
Fix regression with nova-manage floating list

Fixes bug #1032177

If a floating IP is not associated with an instance, nova-manage fails
with:

  local variable 'instance_uuid' referenced before assignment

This is a regression introduced by commit fc82c6d. Simply rename
the local variable to instance_uuid.

Change-Id: Ia6df23c945f0815c65bcfd2f49e8ba3225d03d7f

commit_message:
Allow CLI opts to override auth token and endpoint

Previously, both --os-auth-token and --os-image-url had to be
provided in order for either of them to be used in any API requests.
This breaks the tie between them and allows a user to override
either the auth token or the endpoint returned by Keystone independently
of one another.

Fixes bug 1029586

Change-Id: I8b81be723286c546d9cbd97c8b7d7aa89c03b2d4

commit_message:
Allow control of whether a user can specify a volume mount point.

Since some hypervisors don't support this feature, it makes the
field in the attach form extremely misleading.

Change-Id: I875c63d35b22b6b73314e001dbc1fbdce4363e25

commit_message:
^c shouldn't leave incomplete images in cache

Fixes LP bug 1031842

Use a finally clause for the xattr and sqlite
image cache implementations of open_for_write()
such that if the commit() or rollback() aren't
called and the image remains in the incomplete
dir that it is moved to the invalid dir

Change-Id: Id9a0ac56a8ae9fd03af9ccc4989c9b304c95bdde

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-02 18:52:57.000000000', 'message': 'Use function registration for policy checks

The original policy framework allowed new policy checks to be created
through inheritance.  This is somewhat clunky and unnecessary in
Python.  This change refactors policy.py to allow new policy checks
to be registered using an @register() decorator.  One consequence is
that HttpBrain is deprecated.

Care has been taken to ensure backwards compatibility; deprecation
warnings will be emitted for uses of HttpBrain or the inheritance-
based checks.

(Pull-up from openstack-common.)

Change-Id: Ib11f4581d187d037d2081515d70e325425d68760
'}]
commit_message:
Use function registration for policy checks

The original policy framework allowed new policy checks to be created
through inheritance.  This is somewhat clunky and unnecessary in
Python.  This change refactors policy.py to allow new policy checks
to be registered using an @register() decorator.  One consequence is
that HttpBrain is deprecated.

Care has been taken to ensure backwards compatibility; deprecation
warnings will be emitted for uses of HttpBrain or the inheritance-
based checks.

(Pull-up from openstack-common.)

Change-Id: Ib11f4581d187d037d2081515d70e325425d68760

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-02 01:10:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-08-02 02:07:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think the strategy used throughout glance (and other core projects) is to use:

 LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__)

at the top of the file and then use:

 LOG.debug()

throughout. Would it be possible to apply this to the replicator?

Thanks Mikal! Sorry for being a nitpick! :)

-jay"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-08-02 04:53:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Jay.

All things are possible, and we could move to something else. However, Brian was trying to keep the dependencies of the replicator to a bear minimum (hence why it implements its own glance API client for example). So, I have consciously not used the openstack logging module, but instead used the standard python one.

If we're willing to add a dependency, then I'm happy enough to change the logging code over.

Cheers,
Mikal"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-02 05:25:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think Jay is just suggesting that you implement the logger instantiation pattern the rest of Glance is using:

  import logging
  LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__)
  LOG.debug('...')"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-08-02 05:34:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I don't understand. With the python logging module, you need to setup a handler and formatter before you can log, so I'd still have to do initialization in main():

$ python
Python 2.7.3 (default, Apr 20 2012, 22:44:07) 
[GCC 4.6.3] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import logging
>>> LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__)
>>> LOG.error('hello')
No handlers could be found for logger "__main__"

Or am I somehow misunderstanding the request still?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-08-02 15:42:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

OK, Michael, no worries. I didn't realize we were trying to keep the deps down to a minimum here. Not a problem.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-02 17:09:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Since this is a binary/cli-tool it doesn't matter as much. If this were an importable library it would be very important to use a properly-named logger. It's not a big deal right now."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-02 17:09:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

commit_message:
Add links to image access schema

/v2/schemas/image/access was missing links, both as properties and link
descriptor objects, although /v2/images/<id>/access was returning them
in responses. This change adds the link properties to the schema
response.

Addresses bp api-v2-links

Change-Id: I68e576dadbbe37d4d33d2238ea0e4c798a4a667b

subject: Check instance lock in compute/api
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2284, 'name': 'Eoghan Glynn', 'email': 'eglynn@redhat.com', 'username': 'eglynn'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-07-26 16:57:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Nice and neat!

One tiny suggestion in-line.

Also, just to clarify one thing ... you're leaving the @checks_instance_lock usage in nova/compute/manager.py in order to maintain backward compat for mixed deployments (i.e. new nova-api plus old nova-compute), right?

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:02:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Actually, I'm leaving it in there because it's not entirely clear to me whether anything with access to the rpc API can be trusted. It seems to me that the manager.py lock checks should be the "official" ones and that the ones in api.py are really for optimization...'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:06:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there a tiny race condition between the two checks?

i.e. just an admin locks the server, an in-flight action passes the check in nova/compute/api.py and issues the RPC cast, which then fails silently at the second check in nova/compute/manager.py.

Its a fairly narrow race, but possible. One option would be to add to the RPC context some indication that the lock status has already been checked by RPC caller (I think markmc suggested something similar on IRC earlier).

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/5441/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/1306/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/6618/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/2815/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/2828/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/4958/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:22:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There is, but it was there before, AFAIK. If you've passed the decorator check in manager.py after the lock has been set, then you'll continue with your action. Keeping the check in manager.py keeps the exposure window as small as it can be, I think. I would tend to say that there's a reasonable expectation in a web service that if a reboot and lock action are issued simultaneously, the reboot may or may not succeed, right? As long as we don't corrupt state (we still need the state reversion patch) then we're safe, right?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Well, I think these are two separate races.

Previously (and still the case), we can proceed to complete the action just as the lock is applied, if the check(s) on the lock status just gets in ahead of the modification. As you point out, this is acceptable.

However, now we also have the possibility that the lock modification will occur *between* the two checks on the lock state for a single action. As the first check passes, we then lose the ability to report back to the client that the action did not proceed because the second check failed.

Its a pretty narrow case, but still a possibility I think.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:48:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/5448/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/1313/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/6625/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/2822/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/2835/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/4972/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:59:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ah, I see what you're getting at :)

Well, maybe Mark can comment on that. I still think this leaves us better off than before, but I see your point."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-07-26 21:28:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks good. I have reservations about the increasingly large decorator storm regarding performance and readability that's drifted over Nova. Might be a worthwhile conversation to have (rekindle) at some point in the near future."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-07-26 21:38:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yeah indeed. I think that decorators like this are very straightforward and not as much of a problem as others. It seems like the incredible flexibility we get from dynamic function dispatching makes decorators the "natural" place to tweak behaviors like this, but it could certainly be done in a more organized fashion.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-27 12:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Nice work Dan - this is very close. Some small comments inline.

The main issue is what Eoghan pointed out - I'd like to see a "lock_checked" boolean parameter added to all RPC calls that do locking and have @checks_instance_lock on the server side not re-check the lock if the paramter is True. You'll also want to bump the minor version of the API.

The reason for this is the race condition Eoghan pointed out, the need to retain backwards compat but also it makes it more obvious that in a future version where we remove support for the 1.x RPC API, we can remove the server side locking.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-27 13:48:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-07-30 17:20:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-30 17:43:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work
