'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-07-17 20:32:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Whilst I acknowledge that the V2.0 API spec does not include config_drive, I disagree with the justification for moving this into an extension. The only deployer who has expressed displeasure with the feature is Rackspace. Making this change results in a breaking change for existing users, and establishes KVM as a second class citizen for specced features. Since KVM is used and supported by more OpenStack distributions/deployments than Xen, it seems a better solution from a non-breaking change perspective would be to create an extension that removes the config-drive key.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-07-17 22:01:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mr. MacGown: What breaking change is this introducing?'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-07-17 22:13:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Existing users of diablo and essex who use config-drive expect that it will work out of the box after they've upgraded to Folsom."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-07-17 22:20:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Can you explain how that won't be the case after this patch?"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-07-18 10:09:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Maybe I'm missing something, but I thought the api extension mechanism added new URLs / commands - whereas config_drive is an option to the create call ?

Won't moving this to an extension therfore change that behaviour ?"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-07-18 14:22:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

One minor inline nit-pick.

Chris,
I believe that this patch introduces only the following changes:
- config drive is exposed only if the config drive extension is enabled (which it is, by default)

Phil,
Extensions are allowed to add information to requests and responses. We don't have the mechanism to add them to requests, I suppose, but we frequently use extensions to add resources to responses.

(Iccha correct me if I"m wrong...) This patchset doesn't change how config_drives are passed into create calls. It just changes how they are displayed. Namely, if the extension is enabled, they are displayed in exactly the same way as before. If the extension is disabled, they are not displayed.'}, {'account_id': 4463, 'date': '2012-07-18 14:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yeah, Mark is right. The config_drive only changes the display. The create mechanism works the same irrespective of whether the extension is turned on or off.

And since by default all the extensions are on, the code will continue to work the same way as before, and the user will not notice the difference of the new extension being added.

This only gives the additional option of turning off the config_drive display.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-07-18 14:57:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So it seems just weird to me to make displaying something an extension, when the abilty to use it is part of the core functionality.  That just feels like a source of confusion whating to happen.

How hard is it to just ignore additional bits of a structured output that you;'re not interested in ? 

Extensions as a way to add new functionality (Multinic, security_groups, etc) I get, but this isn't really an extension at all

Are there other presidents for this - and is it really how we want to control/ define the API ?"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-07-18 15:00:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sorry - that was meant to be a 0 rather than a -1 (not sure how I can take a -1 back)'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-18 21:47:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

makes sense and looks good'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-18 21:49:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

According to the api spec the create part should be part of an extension as well, but we haven't defined an easy way to add extra parameters to a post via an extension AFAIK."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-20 18:09:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

commit_message:
Implements config_drive as extension

Adding config drive as an extension allows users to turn it off in case they
do not want to use it. Config drive was not intended to be a part of the core
functionality.

Fixes bug 833331

Change-Id: Icf4b5a21d8cc9df0f140a1a87908ff48c447004b

'}, {'created': '2012-07-27 13:22:19.000000000', 'message': 'Moving where the fixed ip deallocation happens.

Fixes bug 1021352.

In network/manager/deallocate_fixed_ip the call
to mark the IP as no longer allocated occurs before
the call to update security group rules. This means
that if an error occurs in the security group
processing, or if for some reason it is very slow
there is a risk that that the address is reused by
another tenant before the rules relating to this address
have been fully revoked.

Moving the db call to after the call to trigger the
security group refresh would avoid the issue when an
error occurs (the fixed_ip should not be released in
this case).

Change-Id: Iaba1af5c9a17fbbb82e42522b1060773de61550a
'}]
commit_message:
Moving where the fixed ip deallocation happens.

Fixes bug 1021352.

In network/manager/deallocate_fixed_ip the call
to mark the IP as no longer allocated occurs before
the call to update security group rules. This means
that if an error occurs in the security group
processing, or if for some reason it is very slow
there is a risk that that the address is reused by
another tenant before the rules relating to this address
have been fully revoked.

Moving the db call to after the call to trigger the
security group refresh would avoid the issue when an
error occurs (the fixed_ip should not be released in
this case).

Change-Id: Iaba1af5c9a17fbbb82e42522b1060773de61550a

commit_message:
Send a full instance in pre_live_migration.

Change the pre_live_migration method of the compute
rpc API to take a full instance over rpc instead of just
the instance UUID.  This cuts down on database access needed
by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: Ib628d375254fc1539cd79ceaaad83c1c326863b4

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-26 22:46:42.000000000', 'message': 'Make instance_uuid backwards compat actually work.

In some refactoring of the decorator modifications I made for
eebc64f949ccb2acb7462efc18f538f1827985af, I ended up breaking the case
where an instance_uuid was passed to one of the methods that is supposed
to be able to accept either an instance or instance_uuid.  Oops.  :-(

This patch makes them work again, and adds one unit test that
verifies that it works.

These decorators are really ugly right now, but keep in mind that the
2-version stuff is temporary.  As soon as this patch series is finished
(changing methods to take an instance), these decorators will get
simplified.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: Ic1b1269d90e147035c4eb7b4bd47de81eff3ffdc
'}]
commit_message:
Make instance_uuid backwards compat actually work.

In some refactoring of the decorator modifications I made for
eebc64f949ccb2acb7462efc18f538f1827985af, I ended up breaking the case
where an instance_uuid was passed to one of the methods that is supposed
to be able to accept either an instance or instance_uuid.  Oops.  :-(

This patch makes them work again, and adds one unit test that
verifies that it works.

These decorators are really ugly right now, but keep in mind that the
2-version stuff is temporary.  As soon as this patch series is finished
(changing methods to take an instance), these decorators will get
simplified.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: Ic1b1269d90e147035c4eb7b4bd47de81eff3ffdc

commit_message:
Remove get_instance_disk_info from compute rpcapi.

This method is no longer used in any current code, so remove it from the
client side code for the rpcapi.  The server-side code remains (the
compute manager) for backwards compatibility with older versions.

This method was previously used by the scheduler, but was removed by
some refactoring done in cac332c39645286a11c009094a86f62d02752183.

Change-Id: Icb11001ac0880ca8df67b4dd9f0fe1eaca7fa3bb

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for get_diagnostics.

Change the get_diagnostics method of the compute rpc API to take
a full instance over rpc instead of just the instance UUID.
This cuts down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: Ic4db237849230899ad5f2f0780d4c237895a6631

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for finish_revert_resize.

Change the finish_revert_resize method of the compute rpc API to take
a full instance over rpc instead of just the instance UUID.
This cuts down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: Ibe2f8b990cc8f2a3d05e8ba8216a1e74cbcfb67b

commit_message:
Handle local & remote exceptions consistently.

Related to LP 1021373.

When the floating_ips quota threshold is exceeded, this occurs remotely
in the networking service and hence is reported back to the API service
over RPC, via a RemoteError wrapping the original QuotaError exception.

Previously the handling of such RemoteErrors in the native API was
inconsistent with exceptions raised locally within the API service.

Now in both cases, we expose the exception explantion, status etc. in the
response, if the exception type is declared as safe.

This fix is not required on master, as the Folsom RPC failure deserialization
logic renders it unnecessary.

Change-Id: Icf7dcafd1f942f5d81d12587775d6ade4a176932

commit_message:
Don't use uuidgen in install.sh

uuidgen is not present in Ubuntu. This simply reads 16 bytes from
/dev/random and stores their hex representation.

Change-Id: If1152242b024218f20bd4c787e03836f0d5f49cf
Signed-off-by: Tomas Sedovic <tomas@sedovic.cz>

commit_message:
Add encryption support for authentication information in db.

This patch uses an encryption key generated in install.sh to perform
symmetrical encryption on sensitive authentication information stored
in the database for HA operations.

Change-Id: Ifd09f3f566ba3ebd941a6f453953576011b518b9
Signed-off-by: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-07-27 11:39:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

Hi,
I have elaborated in the comments about the port creation. This is required for the creation of the bridge devcice when using the linux bridge. I agree that in some cases the tap device may not be used.
Can you please elaborate on the race condition. I am not sure that I understand.

I would be happy to get this in so that we can enable peoiple to work with the dhcp-agent and linux bridge. This is crucial for our testing and stability. 

An alternative approach would be to do what was done in nova and instaed of having the dnsmasq listening on an interface, it can listen on an ip address. I am not really sure why we need to move to netns (I was unable to get this to work on a number of different devstack instances that I have).

Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-07-27 11:39:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-27 11:39:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

One question'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-07-27 11:39:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

I understand how this addresses the bug, but I'm not sure this is approach we want.  There are two drawbacks: extraneous port & tap device creation and a race condition with the q-agt on managing the bridge.

The real bug is that tap devices need something that speaks in ethernet frames.  For my netns, work I switched to using veths.  I can split that work out into two reviews.  One that fixes this bug and a second that actually uses namespaces (still tracking distro compatibility problems)."}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-07-27 11:39:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Ensure that linuxbridge plugin works with dhcp-agent

Fixes bug 1027194

When working with a standard linux bridge the tapdevice should not
have the IP address configured. This address should be configured
on the bridge.

Change-Id: I0013fd7483c694ef23f875e19dfde1b9b2174d00

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-15 12:31:41.000000000', 'message': 'Support for resizing filesystems directly on root

At the moment, XenServer requires the disk to have a partition
table as well the operating system to be on the first partition.

However, there are cases when the operating system / file system
is directly on the disk with no partition table.  This commit
automatically detects this and resizing these partitions in a
fail-safe manner.  Fixes LP Bug #1024944

Change-Id: I22208d3f8c0c3295de2b19e82b2fd6ba79c9105c
'}]
commit_message:
Support for resizing filesystems directly on root

At the moment, XenServer requires the disk to have a partition
table as well the operating system to be on the first partition.

However, there are cases when the operating system / file system
is directly on the disk with no partition table.  This commit
automatically detects this and resizing these partitions in a
fail-safe manner.  Fixes LP Bug #1024944

Change-Id: I22208d3f8c0c3295de2b19e82b2fd6ba79c9105c

commit_message:
Allow to use SSL with self-signed certificates

SSL certificate validity checks fail with self-signed certificates used
in development or in-house environments. This patch adds a new config
value 'OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_INSECURE_SSL', that allows to disable validity
checks done by keystoneclient, glanceclient and novaclient.

Change-Id: I4d79c1b12ad830540ca30009bd25edde10c1a055

Fixed bug #1026547 : Cyberduck : more informations on how to use it with Swift

commit_message:
Add encryption support for authentication information in db.

This patch uses an encryption key generated in install.sh to perform
symmetrical encryption on sensitive authentication information stored
in the database for HA operations.

Change-Id: Id94cade923280ea1ae40ebdeda9ad6573fb1d14a
Signed-off-by: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-26 04:35:38.000000000', 'message': 'Include architecture in instance base options passed to the scheduler

Commit 31336b35 removed architecture from the instance base_options
passed to _schedule_run_instance().  The architecture specified in
the image is needed by a subsequent patch to the ComputeFilter which
filters compute hosts against the triple (architecture, hypervisor_type,
vm_mode).

Change-Id: I840356979e51de3a6d941fe4ae9610e488383a44
'}]
commit_message:
Include architecture in instance base options passed to the scheduler

Commit 31336b35 removed architecture from the instance base_options
passed to _schedule_run_instance().  The architecture specified in
the image is needed by a subsequent patch to the ComputeFilter which
filters compute hosts against the triple (architecture, hypervisor_type,
vm_mode).

Change-Id: I840356979e51de3a6d941fe4ae9610e488383a44

Enhance nova-manage to set flavor extra specs

blueprint update-flavor-key-value

Enhance nova-manage so that it can add, delete and list key/value pairs for
flavors extra specs.

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for finish_resize.

Change the finish_resize method of the compute rpc API to take
a full instance over rpc instead of just the instance UUID.
This cuts down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I2b0c7cbd2ba9b6243c2c50e69e894d192e230491

"}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-06-21 00:50:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(8 inline comments)

By biggest concern is auth_token middleware where PKI token validation is not configurable. I thought we've agreed on making it configurable."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-06-22 19:18:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (5 inline comments)

Good comments.  I don't think we can safely switch between signed and unsigned tokens on the Keystone side.  On the remote services, if we leave the old code in place, it will do the existing remote lookups, and will only use crypto for new ones."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-28 15:24:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

guang-yee: what exactly are you looking to have configurable?'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-28 16:09:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(32 inline comments)

guang-yee: disregard the above question"}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-06-28 18:28:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

There are a couple of reasons for making it configurable in middleware.

1) flexibility in risk management. For example, some may prefer real-time toke validation as oppose to local signature validate in order to get the most up-to-date token access info. Granted, PKI token does not offer any benefits for real-time token validation. But from risk management standpoint, these kinds of flexibility makes a real difference in deployment.

2) backward compatible. Keystone is a reference implementation. We have our own implementation of Keystone and I am sure others as well. But Keystone middleware is common to all because the service APIs are public. We currently extend Keystone middleware and add HP-specific functionality on top of it. Therefore, preserving backward compatibility is very important. By not making it configurable, you are essentially breaking 3rd party vendors like us. It may also have an impact on rolling upgrade as well.'}, {'account_id': 154, 'date': '2012-06-28 18:30:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Added some idea about supporting both token formats."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-07-03 19:56:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(28 inline comments)

Minor nits inline, mostly stylistic.

This patch doesn't appear to support token revocation, only expiry, and I didn't see mention of how this is to be handled in the bug, wiki entry, or the linked blog post.  Have I missed something?"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-07-11 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-24 14:30:23.000000000', 'message': "Cryptographically Signed tokens

Uses CMS to create tokens that can be verified without network calls.

Tokens are the auth info.  This includes user name and roles.
The auth info is crptographically signed with a private key from Keystone.
The auth info and signature are contatinated into DER format and then
Base64 encoded.

This should be a drop in replacement for the current token production code.
Although  the signed token is longer than the older format, the token is still
a unique stream of Alpha-Numeric charachters.

The 'key' column is added to the SQL schema because SQL alchemy insists on
each table having a primary key.  However primary keys are limited to roughly
250 Characters (768 Bytes,  but there is more than 1 varchar per byte) so the
ID field cannot be used as the primary key anymore.

Bug 1003962

Change-Id: I89b5aa609143bbe09a36bfaf64758c5306e86de7
"}, {'created': '2012-06-19 17:20:06.000000000', 'message': "Cryptographically Signed tokens

Uses CMS to create tokens that can be verified without network calls.

Tokens encapsulate authientication and authorization  information.
This includes user name and roles in JSON.
The JSON document info is cryptographically signed with a private key
from Keystone, in accordance with the Cryp[tographic Message Syntax (CMS)
in DER format and then Base64 encoded.  The header, footer, and line breaks
are stripped to minimize the size,  and  slashesi which are  invalid in Base64
are converted to hyphens.

This should be a drop in replacement for the current token production code.
Although  the signed token is longer than the older format, the token is still
a unique stream of Alpha-Numeric charachters.

The 'key' column is added to the SQL schema because SQL alchemy insists on
each table having a primary key.  However primary keys are limited to roughly
250 Characters (768 Bytes,  but there is more than 1 varchar per byte) so the
ID field cannot be used as the primary key anymore.  The Key field is generated as a hash of the token string.

auth_token needs to stand alone in the other services, and uses
keystone.common.cms in order to verify tokens.
Token needs to have all of the data from the original authenticate code
contained in the signed document, as the authenticate RPC will no longer
be called in mand cases.

The datetime of expiry is signed in the token.

The certificates are accessible via web APIs.  On the remote service side,
certificates needed to authenitcate tokens are stored in /tmp/keystone-signing
by default.  Remote systems use Paste API to read configuration values.
Certificates are retireved only if they are not on the local system.

When authenticating in Keystone systems, it still does the Database checks for
token presence.  This allows Keystone to continue to enforce Timeout and
disabled users.

using DEFAULT-TOKEN for memcache tests
use Signed token as ID for KVS.
Roles have been replaced with marshallable text in the tokens.

Bug 1003962

Change-Id: I89b5aa609143bbe09a36bfaf64758c5306e86de7
"}, {'created': '2012-06-19 18:45:27.000000000', 'message': "Cryptographically Signed tokens

Uses CMS to create tokens that can be verified without network calls.

Tokens encapsulate authientication and authorization  information.
This includes user name and roles in JSON.
The JSON document info is cryptographically signed with a private key
from Keystone, in accordance with the Cryp[tographic Message Syntax (CMS)
in DER format and then Base64 encoded.  The header, footer, and line breaks
are stripped to minimize the size,  and  slashesi which are  invalid in Base64
are converted to hyphens.

This should be a drop in replacement for the current token production code.
Although  the signed token is longer than the older format, the token is still
a unique stream of Alpha-Numeric charachters.

The 'key' column is added to the SQL schema because SQL alchemy insists on
each table having a primary key.  However primary keys are limited to roughly
250 Characters (768 Bytes,  but there is more than 1 varchar per byte) so the
ID field cannot be used as the primary key anymore.  The Key field is generated as a hash of the token string.

auth_token needs to stand alone in the other services, and uses
keystone.common.cms in order to verify tokens.
Token needs to have all of the data from the original authenticate code
contained in the signed document, as the authenticate RPC will no longer
be called in mand cases.

The datetime of expiry is signed in the token.

The certificates are accessible via web APIs.  On the remote service side,
certificates needed to authenitcate tokens are stored in /tmp/keystone-signing
by default.  Remote systems use Paste API to read configuration values.
Certificates are retireved only if they are not on the local system.

When authenticating in Keystone systems, it still does the Database checks for
token presence.  This allows Keystone to continue to enforce Timeout and
disabled users.

using DEFAULT-TOKEN for memcache tests
use Signed token as ID for KVS.
Roles have been replaced with marshallable text in the tokens.

"}, {'created': '2012-07-11 17:56:02.000000000', 'message': "Cryptographically Signed tokens

Uses CMS to create tokens that can be verified without network calls.

Tokens encapsulate authorization information.
This includes user name and roles in JSON.
The JSON document info is cryptographically signed with a private key
from Keystone, in accordance with the Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS)
in DER format and then Base64 encoded.  The header, footer, and line breaks
are stripped to minimize the size,  and slashes which are  invalid in Base64
are converted to hyphens.

This should be a drop in replacement for the current token production code.
Although  the signed token is longer than the older format, the token is still
a unique stream of Alpha-Numeric characters.

The auth token middle_ware is capable of handling both uuid and signed tokens.

To start with, the PKI functionality is disabled.  This will keep from breaking the existing deployments.  However,  it can be enabled with the config value:

[signing]
disable_pki = False

The 'id_hash' column is added to the SQL schema because SQL alchemy insists on
each table having a primary key.  However primary keys are limited to roughly
250 Characters (768 Bytes,  but there is more than 1 varchar per byte) so the
ID field cannot be used as the primary key anymore.  id_hash is a hash of the id column, and should be used for lookups as it is indexed.

middleware/auth_token.py needs to stand alone in the other services, and uses
keystone.common.cms in order to verify tokens.
Token needs to have all of the data from the original authenticate code
contained in the signed document, as the authenticate RPC will no longer
be called in mand cases.

The datetime of expiry is signed in the token.

The certificates are accessible via web APIs.  On the remote service side,
certificates needed to authenitcate tokens are stored in /tmp/keystone-signing
by default.  Remote systems use Paste API to read configuration values.
Certificates are retrieved only if they are not on the local system.

When authenticating in Keystone systems, it still does the Database checks for
token presence.  This allows Keystone to continue to enforce Timeout and
disabled users.

The service catalog has been added to the  signed token.  Although this greatly increases the size of the token,  it makes it consistant with what is fetched during the token authenticate checks

This change also fixes time variations in expiry test.  Although unrelated to the above changes, it was making testing very frustrating.

For the database Upgrade scripts, we now only  bring 'token' up to V1 in 001
script.  This makes it possible to use the same 002 script for both upgrade and initializing a new database.

Upon upgrade, the current UUID tokens are retained in the id_hash and id fields.  The mechanisms to verify uuid tokens work the same as before.  ON downgrade, token_ids are dropped.

    Bug 1003962

Change-Id: I89b5aa609143bbe09a36bfaf64758c5306e86de7
"}, {'created': '2012-07-14 00:22:47.000000000', 'message': "Cryptographically Signed tokens

Uses CMS to create tokens that can be verified without network calls.

Tokens encapsulate authorization information.
This includes user name and roles in JSON.

are converted to hyphens.

Since signed tokens are not validated against the Keystone server,  they
continue to be valid until the expiration time.  This means that even if a user
has their roles revoked or their account disabled, those changes will not take
effect until their token times out.  The prototype for this is Kerberos, which
has the same limitation, and has funtioned sucessfully with it for decades.  It
is possible to set the token time out for much shorter than the default of 8
hours, but that may mean that users tokens will time out prior to completion
of long running tasks.

This should be a drop in replacement for the current token production code.
Although  the signed token is longer than the older format, the token is still
a unique stream of Alpha-Numeric characters.

The auth token middle_ware is capable of handling both uuid and signed tokens.

To start with, the PKI functionality is disabled.  This will keep from breaking
the existing deployments.  However,  it can be enabled with the config value:

[signing]
disable_pki = False

keystone.common.cms in order to verify tokens.
Token needs to have all of the data from the original authenticate code
contained in the signed document, as the authenticate RPC will no longer
be called in mand cases.

The datetime of expiry is signed in the token.

The certificates are accessible via web APIs.  On the remote service side,
certificates needed to authenitcate tokens are stored in /tmp/keystone-signing
by default.  Remote systems use Paste API to read configuration values.
Certificates are retrieved only if they are not on the local system.

When authenticating in Keystone systems, it still does the Database checks for
token presence.  This allows Keystone to continue to enforce Timeout and
disabled users.

The service catalog has been added to the  signed token.  Although this greatly
increases the size of the token,  it makes it consistant with what is fetched
during the token authenticate checks

This change also fixes time variations in expiry test.  Although unrelated to
the above changes, it was making testing very frustrating.

For the database Upgrade scripts, we now only  bring 'token' up to V1 in 001
script.  This makes it possible to use the same 002 script for both upgrade
and initializing a new database.

Upon upgrade, the current UUID tokens are retained in the id_hash and id fields.
The mechanisms to verify uuid tokens work the same as before.  On downgrade,
token_ids are dropped.

    Bug 1003962

commit_message:
Cryptographically Signed tokens

Uses CMS to create tokens that can be verified without network calls.

Tokens encapsulate authorization information.
This includes user name and roles in JSON.
The JSON document info is cryptographically signed with a private key
from Keystone, in accordance with the Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS)
in DER format and then Base64 encoded.  The header, footer, and line breaks
are stripped to minimize the size,  and slashes which are  invalid in Base64
are converted to hyphens.

Since signed tokens are not validated against the Keystone server,  they
continue to be valid until the expiration time.  This means that even if a user
has their roles revoked or their account disabled, those changes will not take
effect until their token times out.  The prototype for this is Kerberos, which
has the same limitation, and has funtioned sucessfully with it for decades.  It
is possible to set the token time out for much shorter than the default of 8
hours, but that may mean that users tokens will time out prior to completion
of long running tasks.

This should be a drop in replacement for the current token production code.
Although  the signed token is longer than the older format, the token is still
a unique stream of Alpha-Numeric characters.

The auth token middle_ware is capable of handling both uuid and signed tokens.

To start with, the PKI functionality is disabled.  This will keep from breaking
the existing deployments.  However,  it can be enabled with the config value:

[signing]
disable_pki = False

The 'id_hash' column is added to the SQL schema because SQL alchemy insists on
each table having a primary key.  However primary keys are limited to roughly
250 Characters (768 Bytes,  but there is more than 1 varchar per byte) so the
ID field cannot be used as the primary key anymore.  id_hash is a hash of the
id column, and should be used for lookups as it is indexed.

middleware/auth_token.py needs to stand alone in the other services, and uses
keystone.common.cms in order to verify tokens.
Token needs to have all of the data from the original authenticate code
contained in the signed document, as the authenticate RPC will no longer
be called in mand cases.

The datetime of expiry is signed in the token.

The certificates are accessible via web APIs.  On the remote service side,
certificates needed to authenitcate tokens are stored in /tmp/keystone-signing
by default.  Remote systems use Paste API to read configuration values.
Certificates are retrieved only if they are not on the local system.

When authenticating in Keystone systems, it still does the Database checks for
token presence.  This allows Keystone to continue to enforce Timeout and
disabled users.

The service catalog has been added to the  signed token.  Although this greatly
increases the size of the token,  it makes it consistant with what is fetched
during the token authenticate checks

This change also fixes time variations in expiry test.  Although unrelated to
the above changes, it was making testing very frustrating.

For the database Upgrade scripts, we now only  bring 'token' up to V1 in 001
script.  This makes it possible to use the same 002 script for both upgrade
and initializing a new database.

Upon upgrade, the current UUID tokens are retained in the id_hash and id fields.
The mechanisms to verify uuid tokens work the same as before.  On downgrade,
token_ids are dropped.

Takes into account changes for "Raise unauthorized if tenant disabled"

    Bug 1003962

Change-Id: I89b5aa609143bbe09a36bfaf64758c5306e86de7

commit_message:
Trim volume type representation.

Fixes cinder aspect of LP 1027281.

Use view builder pattern to only include non-extraneous
volume type attributes in the representation.

Change-Id: I33f1b579fd6ed4ed98fa04e9148e91eca125213e

commit_message:
Remove return values from some compute RPC methods

The checks_instance_lock decorator currently discards any return value
from the functions it wraps. Luckily, none of the callers of these
functions check for a return value.

Since the return values are unused, just remove them. Fixing the
decorator to return them would effectively be a change to the RPC
API.

And since we know the return value is unused, we also know that nothing
checks for the False return from checks_instance_lock() and that too
can be removed.

Change-Id: I8b49107dba51caf52665341e4977de179b6404f6

[{'created': '2012-07-25 17:35:41.000000000', 'message': 'Fix exception handling in libvirt attach_volume()

Currently, the real reason for a failure is dropped when attempting
to unroll the volume connection (with the exception of when it is
VIR_ERR_OPERATION_FAILED). This change uses save_and_reraise_exception()
to correct that so that the actual reason for failure gets logged.

Change-Id: Id47db565c4fb5a88d1a263600b41706dd3419726
'}, {'created': '2012-07-26 14:04:17.000000000', 'message': 'Fix exception handling in libvirt attach_volume()

Currently, the real reason for a failure is dropped when attempting
to unroll the volume connection (with the exception of when it is
VIR_ERR_OPERATION_FAILED). This change uses save_and_reraise_exception()
to correct that so that the actual reason for failure gets logged.

Fixes bug 1029463

Change-Id: Id47db565c4fb5a88d1a263600b41706dd3419726
'}]
commit_message:
Fix exception handling in libvirt attach_volume()

Currently, the real reason for a failure is dropped when attempting
to unroll the volume connection (with the exception of when it is
VIR_ERR_OPERATION_FAILED). This change uses save_and_reraise_exception()
to correct that so that the actual reason for failure gets logged.

Fixes bug 1029463

Change-Id: Id47db565c4fb5a88d1a263600b41706dd3419726

for all image types. This addresses bug 1029532.

I have addressed the reviewer's comments, but there are a couple of things to mention:
- when printing the list of ids for the multiple occurences found, we do a strange trick by concatenating all the ids and then returning the concatenated string to the cliff produce_output method. I did so because it seems there's no way to change the behaviour of the command from show.ShowOne to lister.Lister when emitting the list of ids.
- I have implemented the uuid check but not entirely satisfied with it. We avoid a lot of unnecessary 404, but we are enforcing a specific pattern for the uuid in the client, whereas the API doesn't - it's says just that the field should be "uuid-str", and actually this is not enforced anywhere, because we can plugins that do not extend db_plugin_base_v2. commit_message:
Allow to retrieve objects by name

Fixes bug 979527

xxx-show commands now can accept either an id or a name of the resource to
retrieve, similarly to the "nova get" command. This has been preferred to
using mutually exclusive keyword argument, in order to avoid confusion
with other CLI tools.

NOTE: the current patch allow search by name only for networks.
The restriction will be lifted once name attributes for port and subnets
are added.

Change-Id: Id186139a01c9f2cfc36ca3405b4024bd7780622e

[{'created': '2012-07-26 19:42:22.000000000', 'message': "Avoid using 'is' operator when comparing strings

The 'is' operator compares identity, not value. Python doesn't guarantee

commit_message:
Avoid using 'is' operator when comparing strings

The 'is' operator compares identity, not value. Python doesn't guarantee
that two strings that are the same will also be the same object.

Change-Id: I2d7e7947b14272fa2a82d5e8eefa95dcaba375f7

commit_message:
Add Content-MD5 header to V2 API image download

If an image is downloaded via the V2 API and its checksum is known
(not None), assign the checksum to the Content-MD5 header.

Related to blueprint api-2

Change-Id: Ib34e9800833a6913c992de1a18f9fc331661f057

Candidate for a unit-test?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-07-26 19:00:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-07-26 19:12:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There is a unit test already that passes because of implementation details in CPython.

    >>> a = 'Xen'
    >>> a += 'Server'
    >>> a
    'XenServer'
    >>> a is 'XenServer'
    False
    >>> a == 'XenServer'
    True

but sometimes the is operator works:

    >>> ('Xen' + 'Server') is 'XenServer'
    True

The moral of the story is to not use the is operator when comparing strings"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-26 19:13:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

commit_message:
Fix resizing VDIs on XenServer >= 6

The check used 'is' when it should have been '=='.

Also, a couple of small cleanups to make the code easier to read.

Change-Id: If98892703bc557732093230b023085c4744b8455

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-26 18:49:45.000000000', 'message': "Allow power_off when instance doesn't exist

Certain errors that can occur while booting an instance may leave no
VM on the Xen hypervisor.  This can make that instance undeletable,
since the first step in soft_delete() is to power_off the instance,
and nothing catches the NotFound error thrown if the instance doesn't
exist.  The libvirt support handles the case of a non-existant
instance by ignoring NotFound--after all, a non-existant instance is,
by definition, powered off, right?

Fixes bug 1029132.

Change-Id: I5bffe3b61fe92fc32fb70cab941fa5ecd250df77
"}]
commit_message:
Allow power_off when instance doesn't exist

Certain errors that can occur while booting an instance may leave no
VM on the Xen hypervisor.  This can make that instance undeletable,
since the first step in soft_delete() is to power_off the instance,
and nothing catches the NotFound error thrown if the instance doesn't
exist.  The libvirt support handles the case of a non-existant
instance by ignoring NotFound--after all, a non-existant instance is,
by definition, powered off, right?

Fixes bug 1029132.

Change-Id: I5bffe3b61fe92fc32fb70cab941fa5ecd250df77

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-26 12:29:58.000000000', 'message': "Refactor glance image service code

Fixes bug 1029397

This adds better retry support, making sure that if we need to retry
requests to glance, we cycle through all hosts before potentially
attemping the hosts that failed.  The old random selection could cause
immediate retrying of the same host that failed.

This also adds logging of the host:port that failed and fixes a bug in
the retry test, which didn't actually successfully test retrying.

Tests for new code added.

Change-Id: I400616081e1e547b9ca2e0be622889d3a399a5bf

commit_message:
Refactor glance image service code

Fixes bug 1029397

This adds better retry support, making sure that if we need to retry
requests to glance, we cycle through all hosts before potentially
attemping the hosts that failed.  The old random selection could cause
immediate retrying of the same host that failed.

This also adds logging of the host:port that failed and fixes a bug in
the retry test, which didn't actually successfully test retrying.

Tests for new code added.

Change-Id: I400616081e1e547b9ca2e0be622889d3a399a5bf

commit_message:
Don't import libvirt_utils in disk api.

Updates the virt/disk/api so that we no longer import libvirt_utils.

This fixes issues when using Nova compute with compute drivers other
than libvirt. (xenapi, etc.)

Fixes LP Bug #1029501.

Change-Id: I46ece309480ce0a0941a96371a51d77712c41eb6

Commit eebc64f removed some error logging, presumably by mistake.

If checks_instance_state fails, and the action blocked, users aren't
notified but the error is logged for admins. Changing this behavior
clearly wasn't the intent of the no-db-messaging commit.

Change-Id: I14581171c201770b03cecc77d4a2933c9687ef11
"}, {'created': '2012-07-26 15:53:49.000000000', 'message': "Reinstate instance locked error logging

Commit eebc64f removed some error logging, presumably by mistake.

If checks_instance_state fails, and the action blocked, users aren't

commit_message:
Reinstate instance locked error logging

Commit eebc64f removed some error logging, presumably by mistake.

If checks_instance_state fails, and the action blocked, users aren't
notified but the error is logged for admins. Changing this behavior
clearly wasn't the intent of the no-db-messaging commit.

Change-Id: I14581171c201770b03cecc77d4a2933c9687ef11

AFAICT the only place this is used is in nova/quota.py... and the 'destroy_all_by_project' method there isn't called anywhere outside of tests.

Is this an artifact of deprecated auth that can just go away?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:26:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I just happened to stumble upon this typo while looking at some other code, I then noticed a bug was already opened on it and submitted the review.

I'm not sure I see the connection to the deprecated auth.

There's a variety of unused DB methods and I don't know if nova has ever had a formal policy on removing them. Perhaps that question is best brought up on the mailing list?"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:49:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Agree w/ Johannes, let's fix the typo and then address the idea of removing unused DB calls on mailing list.

commit_message:
update compute_fill_first_cost_fn docstring

The default value for weight of the compute_fill_first_cost_fn is
actually -1.0, which means it does exactly the opposite of what
the function docstring says it does. Update the docstring to
warn people of this fact.

Issue reported via bug #1023827 which was closed as won't fix
but the docs should be clearer. Updated based on feedback.

Change-Id: I56acde254c932a8e66f941aaeb7304665500610f

'}, {'account_id': 2697, 'date': '2012-07-24 21:57:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Looks good.  I'll report back after some testing on my mixed cloud setup.

BTW, I think the commit msg should be more verbose, e.g.

Xen requires specifying both the driver name and type attributes when defining disks.  E.g. the following disk XML snippet

  <disk type='file' device='disk'>
    <driver type='qcow2'/>
    <source file='/tmp/disk0.qcow2'/>
    <target dev='xvda'/>
  </disk>
 
produces incorrect configuration in the xen tools

  (uname file:/tmp/disk0.qcow2)

Including the driver name fixes this

  <disk type='file' device='disk'>
    <driver name='tap' type='qcow2'/>
    <source file='/tmp/disk0.qcow2'/>
    <target dev='xvda'/>
  </disk>

produces

  (uname tap:qcow2:/tmp/disk0.qcow2)"}, {'account_id': 1119, 'date': '2012-07-24 22:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-24 22:24:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Some points inline

Kinda concerned that, for no particular reason, we're setting driver name where we never set it before - i.e. in the kvm and qemu case, we're setting it to 'qemu'  in imagebackend

I guess it only makes a difference where libvirt is configured with allow_disk_format_probing ... and perhaps we want Nova to override that anyway."}, {'account_id': 1119, 'date': '2012-07-25 10:46:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-07-25 10:49:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Kinda concerned that, for no particular reason, we're setting driver
> name where we never set it before - i.e. in the kvm and qemu case,
> we're setting it to 'qemu' in imagebackend

I explicitly suggested that - previously  volume.py would set it, but imagebackend.py would not set it - this is an inconsistency we want to fix.

> I guess it only makes a difference where libvirt is configured with
> allow_disk_format_probing ... and perhaps we want Nova to override that anyway.

No, that's related the driver_type setting which we already have set, not the driver_name."}, {'account_id': 1119, 'date': '2012-07-25 10:58:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-25 11:17:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Doesn't seem to work

> > Kinda concerned that, for no particular reason, we're setting driver name where we never set it before - i.e. in the kvm and qemu case, we're setting it to 'qemu' in imagebackend
> 
> I explicitly suggested that - previously volume.py would set it, but imagebackend.py would not set it - this is an inconsistency we want to fix.

Cool.

> > I guess it only makes a difference where libvirt is configured with allow_disk_format_probing ... and perhaps we want Nova to override that anyway.
>
> No, that's related the driver_type setting which we already have set, not the driver_name.

Both AFAICS:

    if (driver->allowDiskFormatProbing) {
        caps->defaultDiskDriverName = NULL;
        caps->defaultDiskDriverType = NULL;
    } else {
        caps->defaultDiskDriverName = "qemu";
        caps->defaultDiskDriverType = "raw";
    }'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-25 13:24:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Nicely done. I think I'd like to have seem some coverage of this stuff in the test_get_guest_config tests, but we're not testing device config in those tests so ... OK.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 1119, 'date': '2012-07-25 22:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

The SmokeStack failure / errors seem to be unrelated to this change. Daniel, Mark, can you confirm this?'}, {'account_id': 2697, 'date': '2012-07-26 16:47:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

The SmokeStack failure doesn't seem related.  If I'm parsing the log correctly, failure seems to be in the EC2 api, which doesn't use this code at all AFAICT."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:05:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:05:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Yep. The SmokeStack failure was unrelated alright. Subsequent runs show this to run fine...

XenServer is broken at the movement so sadly results won't post here until that fixed... in any case that won't hold up the upstream gate so this should be a go."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-26 17:23:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Verified

    <source file='/tmp/disk0.qcow2'/>
    <target dev='xvda'/>
  </disk>

produces incorrect configuration in the xen tools

  (uname file:/tmp/disk0.qcow2)

Including the driver name fixes this

  <disk type='file' device='disk'>
    <driver name='tap' type='qcow2'/>
    <source file='/tmp/disk0.qcow2'/>
    <target dev='xvda'/>
  </disk>

produces

  (uname tap:qcow2:/tmp/disk0.qcow2)

Change-Id: Id984e0c431b6fc743a39e6e6f3dc3eb289fbb43a

commit_message:
libvirt driver: set driver name consistently

Add pick_disk_driver_name to utils, to be able to set driver_name
consistently across volume and imagebackend. This is mostly required for
xen.

Xen requires specifying both the driver name and type attributes when
defining disks.  E.g. the following disk XML snippet

  <disk type='file' device='disk'>
    <driver type='qcow2'/>
    <source file='/tmp/disk0.qcow2'/>
    <target dev='xvda'/>
  </disk>

produces incorrect configuration in the xen tools

  (uname file:/tmp/disk0.qcow2)

Including the driver name fixes this

  <disk type='file' device='disk'>
    <driver name='tap' type='qcow2'/>
    <source file='/tmp/disk0.qcow2'/>
    <target dev='xvda'/>
  </disk>

produces

  (uname tap:qcow2:/tmp/disk0.qcow2)

Change-Id: Id984e0c431b6fc743a39e6e6f3dc3eb289fbb43a

Thanks for the comments.
All of the agents have changed. In the past they would exit if they do not receive the configuration file as input. Now that they are using the common configuration, there are already default values that are bound. This ensures that the agents can work with and without configuration files. By defualt the configuration file /etc/quantum/quantum.conf will be used if it exists.
Hope that this clarifies things.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-26 16:25:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have not yet looked closely at this patch set, but noticed that two of the test_<plugin>_config.py files are being deleted (lb and ryu), and one is being modified (ovs). I have been having issues with some if these tests on master, so maybe deleting them is appropriate. But we need to decide whether this sort of config testing is needed at the plugin level, and either keep all three or delete all three. If they are kept, I recommend moving them to the plugin-specific unit test directories."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-26 16:25:20.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-26 16:25:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

commit_message:
Enable agents and plugins to use the same configuration file.

The change also implements blueprint agent-logging (this
was due to the fact that the existing logging in the agents
did not work with the change)

Devstack support for the above is in
https://review.openstack.org/10267

Notes:
- The service and agent can be run with multiple configuration
  files by using the CLI parameters --config-file <filename>
- The agent now makes use of the logging and debugging flags
  defined in quantum.conf. This follows the standard common
  configuration command line rules.

Change-Id: I3bd7701526a950c360d7c2cf14b31045010b46ca

Replace subprocess.check_output with Popen

The check_output method does not exist in python 2.6

Fixes bug 1029014

commit_message:
refactor all uses of the `qemu-img info` command

* nova/virt/images.py: Define a single function that
calls `qemu-img info` in a robust manner, by avoiding
locale issues etc.
* nova/virt/libvirt/utils.py: Define secondary functions
to parse items returned from images.qemu_img_info().
* nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py: Use the libvirt.utils functions.
* nova/virt/disk/api.py: Likewise.
* nova/tests/test_libvirt.py: Remove no longer needed stub
for utils.execute('qemu-img info'). Adjust to a more restrictive
`qemu-img info` format, and more robust calling signature.
* nova/tests/test_imagebackend.py: Adjust to moved method.

Change-Id: I739dd246410c215f401ebd3a92b8207f46e8fb9a

commit_message:
Generate AUTHORS and ChangeLog for devstack-gate.

Bug: 1027344

Inline with changes in other projects, generate AUTHORS
and ChangeLog to include in release package.

* .gitignore
  Ignore these 2 files.

* MANIFEST.in
  Include them in the package.

* setup.py
  Command class to generate these files, from openstack.common.

* devstackgate/openstack/common/setup.py
  Import from openstack.common project.

* openstack-common.conf
  Configuration file to sync changes using the update script.

Change-Id: Ia08d70600e012be7759a03f3afe21aa09b804262

Hi Dan,

Totally open to correct on this, but I think we *may* still have a problem with the swift test teardown, assuming the same swift instance & account is used for py26 and py27 Jenkins jobs

A race between S3 object deletion in near-concurrent py26/py27 test runs was the basis of a nasty intermittent failure case that took quite a while to track down coming up to the Essex release. So I think we need to be careful not to introduce a similar race for swift.

Would it make sense to generate a per-test unique container name for swift, in the same way as we do currently for S3:

 https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/tests/functional/store_utils.py#L206

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-07-20 14:32:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-07-20 14:34:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Store swift images in separate containers.

Updates the swift storage backend so that when using multi tenant
each images gets stored in a separate container.

As part of this change the unit tests were updated to generate unique
swift container names for each test. This acts as a container prefix
in multi-tenant mode so the tests were also updated to cleanup all
swift containers matching the container name prefix as well.

The motivation for this change is so that we can set swift read/write
permissions on each individual image.

Partially implements blueprint: swift-tenant-specific-storage.

Change-Id: I43f33594fb40dee33ef52e8ae873722e20b09a10

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for detach_volume.

Change the detach_volume method of the compute rpc API to take
a full instance over rpc instead of just the instance UUID.
This cuts down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: Ibc5e4f16c393bf97fcc4fe9b76e6b435eb99de87

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for confirm_resize.

Change the confirm_resize method of the compute rpc API to take
a full instance over rpc instead of just the instance UUID.
This cuts down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I58313564b240c6b55de1849efc2d5d9031a1c97c

commit_message:
Remove unused methods from compute rpcapi.

Remove some deprecated methods from the compute rpcapi.  These methods
remain in the compute manager code, but there is no need to have them
here in the client side code since they aren't used and we don't want
any new code trying to use them.

Change-Id: I0ae2cd3f25339d91fbd27f8a157b3f95e2acbc6f

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for check_can_live_migrate_source.

Change the check_can_live_migrate_source method of the compute
rpc API to take a full instance over rpc instead of just the instance
UUID.  This cuts down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: Ifc655fb86c94adc9a64e878a89a77342313cace2

commit_message:
Add git commit message validation to hacking.py

Adds N801: git commit title should provide a description

Change-Id: Ic6334b20f5f06631b7a5579a4d1b2303685463eb

commit_message:
Allow 201 status for volume creation.

Lines up Tempest with the changed proposed to nova here:

  https://review.openstack.org/10047

To avoid a chicken-and-egg scenario, as Tempest gates nova merges,
we allow either 200 or 201 status for a temporary transition period.

Change-Id: I14a59b9e0a52c37cb9ce475a71c5f91390b525d5

commit_message:
Fix nova configuration loading

It seems some option handling within nova has changed, so we need
to update our use of the configuration object. These changes ensure
that the options we care about are registered before they are used.

Change-Id: I0dd34f620eed5f43af6da5b02f9c41d35287c275
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Add run_tests flag to run only selenium tests.

The new Jenkins job to run the selenium tests is running all of the
python27 unittests as well which have their own job. Add a new flag,
--only-selenium, to run only the selenium tests. This will allow
Jenkins to better partition work and prevent redundancy.

Change-Id: I70aac3b843434736159c4266b41f6ebd1f5109c7

Hey Monty,

This is causing all sorts of fail when I try to create a tarball. Apparently I have to install PBR before running sdist now? That seems bad.

Also, the commit message seems lacking. PBR? (I'm not sure if your really talking about Pabst Blue Ribbon or Pro Bull Riding.)

I like the idea of standardizing how we do versioning though. :)"}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-07-18 03:46:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hey Dan!

I'll clean up a few things in pbr itself and then make a better commit message.

Installing it before you make a tarball will be required (which is why it's listed in setup_requires) because the code itself drives both the version code and the dependency tracking code in setup.py.

For debs and rpms you should be able to model that via build-requires. I don't have a GREAT suggestion for 100% self-contained tarball creation other than installation of pbr on the host that's creating the tarball. We can chat through options on IRC or something if that seems too onerous of of an idea of course!"}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-07-18 03:50:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-18 03:57:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Use PBR for versioning.

pbr contains the code that used to be in opestack.common setup and
version.  It gets bootstrapped for python via setup_requires, and
then installs a set of setuptools entry_points which register the
various hooks needed to rework how version and dependency processing
happens. Additionally, it takes care of other things that our
projects all standardly do, such as Authors and ChangeLog creation,
sphinx standard locations and setuptools-git dependencies.

Uptream code is managed in OpenStack's gerrit at openstack-dev/pbr
and can be found on pypi.

If we can get on this bandwagon, we should be able to manage this via
normal python dependencies rather than copying code into the projects
via openstack.common's update.py.

Change-Id: I86dd49bb6001c0612d7ac1b015b2757dabb49d14

we should also send a note to the list, b/c at this point, any changes to the v2 proposal (even minor ones) should result in a general heads up to folks.  

My feeling on uniqueness is that generally with an API like this we do not enforce that names are unique, since underlying operations are all done with UUIDs."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-07-26 05:59:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

in case it wasn't clear, -1 was because we need to finalize some discussions on this, not because of any specific issues with the code."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-07-26 05:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I have a general question on this - at some point in the 1.1 API support we had introduced support for kwargs. I am guessing there is some reason why we moved away from that in v2?'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-07-26 05:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Would it be possible that you send a mail to the list and we discuss it at Mondays meeting.
In the mean time the code looks good.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-07-26 05:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Code looks good.
Questions:
1. Why is the name not unique? If someone is going to develop a UI to display quantum networks then a name is a very good way of displaying the information. The fact that the names are not unique may be problematic (I recall that there was an issue with the devstack/tempest with the names)
2. Do you plan on updating the API definitions on the wiki?
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-07-26 05:59:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Is it should unique? nova's instance name is not unique, but keysonte's username is unique.

We can have a discuss if we should keep it unique."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-26 05:59:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-24 18:27:23.000000000', 'message': 'Xen: Validate VHD footer timestamps.

This is a sanity check to ensure the footer timestamps on a VHD are
reasonable (e.g. not in the future). This condition can occur if the
local time for the source and destination machines in a migration are
not in agreement, requiring an adjustment to /etc/localtime and/or NTP
reconfiguration.

Without this check there is a risk of importing a corrupt VHD into the
SR causing the entire SR to become corrupted.

Change-Id: I17228e50d6f54632f3bfc32a682e511f876517ec
'}]
commit_message:
Xen: Validate VHD footer timestamps.

This is a sanity check to ensure the footer timestamps on a VHD are
reasonable (e.g. not in the future). This condition can occur if the
local time for the source and destination machines in a migration are
not in agreement, requiring an adjustment to /etc/localtime and/or NTP
reconfiguration.

Without this check there is a risk of importing a corrupt VHD into the
SR causing the entire SR to become corrupted.

Change-Id: I17228e50d6f54632f3bfc32a682e511f876517ec

code.

commit_message:
Don't log debug auth token when using cinder.

Updates a log messages in the Nova cinderclient function so
it doesn't log the auth token from the request context.

Also properly localizes the log message.

Fixes LP Bug #1029049.

Change-Id: I89120f0e9b7a33c00b9b4b629d61d44d0e9b518f

commit_message:
Shrink Simple Scheduler

* The same functionality exists in the filter scheduler, except for
  nova volumes. So just keep nova-volume scheduling here.
* Add very basic Simple Scheduler testing
* Simple Scheduler will be completely removed after Folsom release

Change-Id: Ia2a2b26bc67cf152963533d68a774f454d763cbd

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for check_can_live_migrate_destination.

Change the check_can_live_migrate_destination method of the compute
rpc API to take a full instance over rpc instead of just the instance
UUID.  This cuts down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I98a403fc4af7c3660c5144e532a318151c6c3b54

commit_message:
tests: remove misleading docstrings on libvirt tests

These docstrings take precedence over the method name,
to identify the test in the results.  So just remove
these misleading docstrings as they don't give extra
info over the method name itself.

Change-Id: I4c415f8c4be588f5de751ab8e4d21e85a18f6b75

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for attach_volume.

Change the attach_volume method of the compute rpc API to take a
full instance over rpc instead of just the instance UUID.  This cuts
down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I85ad29e84b5e97a3f918059b10e2309312756050

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for get_console_output.

Change the get_console_output method of the compute rpc API to take a
full instance over rpc instead of just the instance UUID.  This cuts
down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I114081fceddc2c7226aab9bd560f3664000a43af

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for suspend_instance.

Change the suspend_instance method of the compute rpc API to take a full
instance over rpc instead of just the instance UUID.  This cuts down on
database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: If881fb419a52a2486b2e7b85b4d58a17f72c48a6

commit_message:
Send a full instance via rpc for (un)pause_instance.

Change the pause_instance and unpause_instance methods of the compute
rpc API to take a full instance over rpc instead of just the instance
UUID.  This cuts down on database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: Ia7e31428c7d2edb9a0c4d0958f1c7774742ea1cd

commit_message:
Don't use rpc to lock/unlock an instance.

Instead of converting this method to send a full instance over rpc
instead of just an instance UUID, this patch removes the usage of rpc
for this operation entirely.  All it's doing is a database update.  RPC
is expensive, so cut out the middle-man.

One functional difference with this approach is that the db update is
now synchronous on the API node, instead of kicking off an async message
to a compute node to handle it.  This seems fine, though.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I15ceb7625425ab097eebd5b7dd3606a171329f97

commit_message:
Convert reboot_instance to take a full instance.

Convert the reboot_instance method in the compute rpc API to take a full
instance via rpc instead of just the instance UUID.  This cuts down on
database access needed by nova-compute.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: Id2c455f66966a9b446e5bbbe542ed3a2b0655289

commit_message:
Include name in a primitive Instance.

This ensures that the name of an instance will be present in the result
of jsonutils.to_primitive(Instance).  The name isn't a column.  It's a
property that gets generated dynamically by the Instance class.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I45914ed55f2c037ee2efd7775bd57fbde36a2116

[{'created': '2012-07-23 19:53:39.000000000', 'message': 'Make new versions of decorators in compute manager.

This patch modifies two decorators in the compute manager:
checks_instance_lock and wrap_instance_fault.  Both of these assume that
the function they are wrapping takes two positional arguments: context
and instance_uuid.  The core of these decorators has been split out into
functions and each decorator now has two versions.

   1) The same as before.

   2) The _new variant will be used for functions as they are converted
      to accept a full instance via RPC instead of just the instance
      UUID.  For backwards compatibility, they will actually accept
      either one.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I93e331706aed1c97877655ce54784a0dbd8de89e

commit_message:
Update decorators in compute manager.

This patch modifies two decorators in the compute manager:
checks_instance_lock and wrap_instance_fault.  Both of these assumed that
the function they are wrapping takes two positional arguments: context
and instance_uuid.  They will automatically adapt to the new form that
the functions they wrap will be taking.  These functions will all be
modified to take either a full instance dict or an instance_uuid for
backwards compatibility.

Part of blueprint no-db-messaging.

Change-Id: I93e331706aed1c97877655ce54784a0dbd8de89e

Cool, thanks for looking at the nit picky stuff.  One other thing I didn't touch on is your commit message, but since this pertains specifically to your driver it shouldn't be an issue I don't think."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-07-18 11:28:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ok, this generally looks like excellent work. I'd like to see it merged rather than getting into nitpicking which would mostly apply to the existing code too.

Some comments for the future, though

The patch could have been split up into a nice patch series. There would have been a bunch of patches which did the initial groundwork (like fixing existing docstrings, making get_lun_details() raise an exception, ... etc etc.) and these could have been merged and review very quickly. Then you could have separate patches for volume types and snapshots and these would have been smaller, more easily reviewed and reviewed/merged quicker.

See also: https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg13742.html

One change that might be worth making in Folsom (where perhaps backwards compat with the Essex netapp driver isn't such a great concern) and certainly in Cinder, would be to use an option group for the driver configuration - i.e. instead of:

  [DEFAULT]
  verbose = True
  ...

  netapp_wsdl_url = ...
  netapp_login = ...

you could have:

  [DEFAULT]
  verbose = True
  ...

  [netapp]
  wsdl_url = ...
  login = ...

all you would need to do would be e.g.

  netapp_opts = [
      cfg.StrOpt('wsdl_url',
      ...
      ]

  FLAGS = flags.FLAGS
  FLAGS.register_opts(netapp_opts, 'netapp')


Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-07-24 19:04:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I haven't seen any activity on this change. Is it going to be approved?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-25 19:28:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-07-25 19:28:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Looks sane at least, and is all self-contained to the netapp driver, so in it goes!'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-07-25 19:29:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Add support for snapshots and volume types to netapp driver.

This is a continuation of blueprint netapp-volume-driver.

Change-Id: Ic79a98f3949c815f532e52a9b9d45ad7d8aa99ec

commit_message:
Moves bootstrap LESS back to openstack_dashboard.

Moving the entire bootstrap dir into the horizon module
caused some unexpected complexities. For the time being,
javascript will go into Horizon while CSS/LESS will
go into OpenStack Dashboard.

Change-Id: Ief3a48f2124667e936312f818baeddb6c7c290dc

[{'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-07-21 23:32:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Can you please confirm if this fix breaks other distros? You don't have to actually install them, you could just ask what the lockfile looks like on the mailing list..."}, {'account_id': 4987, 'date': '2012-07-21 23:56:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is not related to a particular distro I suppose - the format is determined by the lockfile package and it has been changed the last and only time in 2010: http://code.google.com/p/pylockfile/source/detail?r=102&path=/branches/packages/lockfile/__init__.py

Perhaps the author of the original patch https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/2fbccc0c693193533284330325f5803c8c6ce52a had a 2010 version of lockfile?

However, I think I should also change the unit tests for this.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:27:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

If the patch is not ubuntu specific, please drop references to ubuntu from the commit message, it will confuse distro packagers.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-07-23 09:07:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

You must have a blank line immediately following the first line of the commit message. As per the HACKING file, the body of the commit message should not rely on external sources for the description of the problem, so please replace "Fix exactly as in the bug description" with the actual description of what you fixed. Finally the bug number is also better placed immediately before the Change-Id line.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-23 17:34:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Fix wrong regex in cleanup_file_locks.

The sentinel filename actually has form hostname-threadid.pid,
not hostname.threadid-pid.
Launchpad bug 1018586.
Change-Id: I09c01e0e63ee704b1485c196dc0b396ee03b2e5c

commit_message:
Inject instance metadata into xenstore

When using Xenserver, inject instance metadata into the xenstore, for
the use of the instance.  Implements blueprint xenstore-metadata.

Change-Id: I88a59f1b783eaaaef6ba5efd8bd448aece2f869c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-25 22:28:43.000000000', 'message': "Allow soft deletes from any state

At some point in the past, the compute manager's delete() method had
its @check_instance_state() decorator updated to allow deletes to be
performed from any combination of vm_state and task_state.  This same
change was not made to the soft_delete() method, and so soft_delete()
is only available if the task_state is clear, meaning that instances
that are put into ERROR state with task_state set to something are
effectively undeletable, if FLAGS.reclaim_instance_interval is set to
some non-zero value (which is what causes the API DELETE call to use
soft_delete() as opposed to delete()).  This patch updates the
@check_instance_state() on soft_delete() to match that on delete(),
and fixes bug 1029130 and bug 1029133.  This patch also partially
fixes bug 1029132, but more needs to be done to completely fix that
bug.

Change-Id: I78878110c696280f2bc28434433814884a526264
"}]
commit_message:
Allow soft deletes from any state

At some point in the past, the compute manager's delete() method had
its @check_instance_state() decorator updated to allow deletes to be
performed from any combination of vm_state and task_state.  This same
change was not made to the soft_delete() method, and so soft_delete()
is only available if the task_state is clear, meaning that instances
that are put into ERROR state with task_state set to something are
effectively undeletable, if FLAGS.reclaim_instance_interval is set to
some non-zero value (which is what causes the API DELETE call to use
soft_delete() as opposed to delete()).  This patch updates the
@check_instance_state() on soft_delete() to match that on delete(),
and fixes bug 1029130 and bug 1029133.  This patch also partially
fixes bug 1029132, but more needs to be done to completely fix that
bug.

Change-Id: I78878110c696280f2bc28434433814884a526264

Previously both length="100" and length=100 would work. But now with this patch only length=100 works. Not sure if this will break some client's code. Is there an API spec that defines what's the correct type? Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 2419, 'date': '2012-07-22 20:03:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2419, 'date': '2012-07-22 20:12:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Good points raised in the reviews! 

Based on the comments, I've change the validation logic on the length from failing if the length isn't an int to fail in the case that the length can't be cast to an int. If length is supplied as either an int or a string representation of an int, the code will pass through as it did in the past. If the length can't be converted to an int, a 400 error will be returned. This maintains compatibility with the old behavior while still checking and returning a more descriptive error code in the case that the length has a value that can't be converted to an integer.

I've also added another test for the specific case in which the length is set to either an int, or a string representation of an int. The test that I had earlier for testing whether the length is a non-integer stays the same."}, {'account_id': 2419, 'date': '2012-07-22 20:17:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

In answer to the question, "Is there a spec that specifies what should be returned?", there is none that I'm aware of. The documentation is underspecified in general.

Should a bug be opened against the documentation? Seems like in general, this is a known issue with the documentation.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-22 20:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

commit_message:
Return 400 in get_console_output for bad length.

Fixes bug 1027069. Prior to this fix if the length in the
request body was set to a non-integer value a error code of 500
was returned. The documentation also shows an integer in the
example request body.

The fix tests if the optional length is provided and
if it is either an "int" or "long". If not, a 400 error
is returned.

Additionally, cleaned up some error message to be more
descriptive.

Change-Id: I27a66fb1111e74665969f98e1101a9c37c665abc

commit_message:
Handle NULL deleted_at in migration 112.

A NULL value in `instance.deleted_at` will cause the migration to break.
In the absence of instance deleted_at timestamp, we should be
conservative and skip cleanup.

Fixes bug 1029129

Change-Id: Ieb978281bc55727fb7db02ddc8c3e0fd6c8814f0

deleted floating IPs.

Change-Id: I30d2e716e931400ca4b798b51bb26a73a7747808
'}]
commit_message:
Allow floating IP pools to be deleted

Fixes bug #1022237

If you delete all the floating IPs associated with a floating IP, the
pool still shows up in os-floating-ip-pools extension.

Fix this by using model_query() in the DB layer so that we ignore
deleted floating IPs.

Change-Id: I30d2e716e931400ca4b798b51bb26a73a7747808

commit_message:
Raise unauthorized if tenant disabled (bug 988920)

If the client attempts to explicitly authenticate against a disabled
tenant, keystone should return HTTP 401 Unauthorized.

Change-Id: I49fe56b6ef8d9f2fc6b9357472dae8964bb9cb9c

commit_message:
Adds the word "infrastructure" to the high availability guide.
Changes the pom.xml to 1.3.1 because 1.4.0 is still a snapshot.

Need to trigger the job and wanted clarity on what type of HA
the guide talks about.

Change-Id: I8ed8f1364f571ae3a4e4effb7297bdc94ec40a5b

commit_message:
Add missing tempfile import to libvirt driver.

import tempfile in the libvirt driver.  This is needed in
_create_shared_storage_test_file().  I saw this come up on the mailing
list:

    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-July/000192.html

Change-Id: Ib327772d61be0202b257049d8aca3d04819a48f5

commit_message:
Modifies _is_opt_registered fcn to check for duplicate opts

This change fixes bug 999307

Currently, the check for duplicate options is done by checking
whether they are the same object. The proposed fix is to check whether
all the object fields have the same value.

Change-Id: I2b72d630a0c8821df1d81e25d316d8d9195be492

[{'created': '2012-07-25 12:52:19.000000000', 'message': "Define cross-driver standardized vm_mode values

Currently the XenAPI driver allows for a 'vm_mode' parameter to
be set against an instance to determine whether it is launched
a paravirt or fullvirt domain. This allows the values 'pv', 'hv'
and 'hvm'.

The libvirt driver also needs to be extended to allow a 'vm_mode'
parameter, and to facilitate deployment of heterogeneous Nova
compute farms, it is desirable to have standardization of the
VM mode values across all drivers.

To address this, the nova.compute.vm_mode module is introduced
which defines a set of constants. The constants provide four
possible vm modes:

 - vm_mode.XEN = 'xen' - for Xen 3.0 paravirt ABI
 - vm_mode.HVM = 'hvm' - for native ABI
 - vm_mode.UML = 'uml' - for User Mode Linux paravirt ABI
 - vm_mode.EXE = 'exe' - for container virt executable ABI

The existing 'pv' value from XenAPI is deprecated, because it
is ambiguous - both Xen and UML are paravirt, and other
paravirt hypervisor ABIs also exist

The existing 'hv' value is also deprecated since it duplicates
the other existing 'hvm' value.

The 'vm_mode.get_from_instance' method will extract the
vm_mode value for an instance. It normalizes the value to
all lower case, translates 'hv' and 'pv' into the new
values for back compat, and validates that the value
matches one of the defined constants

The XenAPI and libvirt drivers are then updated to use the
nova.compute.vm_mode constants instead of bare strings

Change-Id: I23efc5dc1528b0d8472d752a8a30f55c85310b21
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

 - vm_mode.UML = 'uml' - for User Mode Linux paravirt ABI
 - vm_mode.EXE = 'exe' - for container virt executable ABI

is ambiguous - both Xen and UML are paravirt, and other

nova.compute.vm_mode constants instead of bare strings.

to exercise the new codepaths. A new test_vmmode.py
case is also written to fully exercise the logic

NB, previously the libvirt driver would set 'guest.os_type'
to 'linux' to request Xen paravirt. This is a legacy value,
with libvirt preferring the string 'xen'. So although the
new code sets a different value for Xen paravirt os_type,
the functional result is unchanged.

Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Define cross-driver standardized vm_mode values

Currently the XenAPI driver allows for a 'vm_mode' parameter to
be set against an instance to determine whether it is launched
a paravirt or fullvirt domain. This allows the values 'pv', 'hv'
and 'hvm'.

The libvirt driver also needs to be extended to allow a 'vm_mode'
parameter, and to facilitate deployment of heterogeneous Nova
compute farms, it is desirable to have standardization of the
VM mode values across all drivers.

To address this, the nova.compute.vm_mode module is introduced
which defines a set of constants. The constants provide four
possible vm modes:

 - vm_mode.XEN = 'xen' - for Xen 3.0 paravirt ABI
 - vm_mode.HVM = 'hvm' - for native ABI
 - vm_mode.UML = 'uml' - for User Mode Linux paravirt ABI
 - vm_mode.EXE = 'exe' - for container virt executable ABI

The existing 'pv' value from XenAPI is deprecated, because it
is ambiguous - both Xen and UML are paravirt, and other
paravirt hypervisor ABIs also exist

The existing 'hv' value is also deprecated since it duplicates
the other existing 'hvm' value.

The 'vm_mode.get_from_instance' method will extract the
vm_mode value for an instance. It normalizes the value to
all lower case, translates 'hv' and 'pv' into the new
values for back compat, and validates that the value
matches one of the defined constants

The XenAPI and libvirt drivers are then updated to use the
nova.compute.vm_mode constants instead of bare strings.
The test_xenapi.py test case is updated to set 'vm_mode'
to exercise the new codepaths. A new test_vmmode.py
case is also written to fully exercise the logic

NB, previously the libvirt driver would set 'guest.os_type'
to 'linux' to request Xen paravirt. This is a legacy value,
with libvirt preferring the string 'xen'. So although the
new code sets a different value for Xen paravirt os_type,
the functional result is unchanged.

DocImpact
blueprint hypervisor-code-consolidation
Change-Id: I23efc5dc1528b0d8472d752a8a30f55c85310b21
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
